examples.hebrew: כָּתַבְתִּי מְכָתָב לַחֲבֵרִי הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: I wrote a letter to my friend today.

examples.hebrew: כָּתַבְתָּ לִי מִכְתָב מַמָּשׁ יָפֶה בְּיוֹם הוּלֶדֶת שֶׁלִּי.
examples.translation: You wrote me a really beautiful letter for my birthday.

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ כָּתַבְתְּ אֶת הַמִּכְתָּב הַזֶּה בַּיּוֹם שֶׁעָבַר.
examples.translation: You wrote this letter yesterday.

katav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root כ.ת.ב is associated with writing and lettering.

idioms.usage: הַכְּתַב יָד שֶׁלּוֹ קָשֶׁה לְהַבָּנָה.
כּוֹתֵב הַסֵּפֶר מוּכָּר בְּכָל הָעוֹלָם.

examples.hebrew: בֵּית-הַסֵפֶר שֶׁלִי לָמַדְתִּי אוֹתוֹ הָיָה מְאֹד מַעֲנִיֵן.
examples.translation: The school where I studied was very interesting.

examples.hebrew: לָמַדְתָּ לְנַגֵּן בְּגִיטָרָה בִּזְמַן הַקוֹרוֹנָה.
examples.translation: You learned to play the guitar during the corona time.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שסיימת את הלימודים, מה לָמַדְתְּ?
examples.translation: After you finished your studies, what did you learn?

lamad.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ל.מ.ד is associated with learning and education.

idioms.usage: אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִלְמוֹד בְּכָל רֶגַע.

idioms.trl: there is no end to learning
idioms.usage: כְּמוֹ שֶׁאוֹמְרִים, אֵין סוֹף לְלִמּוּד.

mng: to pretend to be a student
[archaic or poetic] to cause to learn

examples.hebrew: קָרָאתִּי אֶת הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה אֶתְמוֹל בַּלַּיְלָה.
examples.translation: I read this book last night.

examples.hebrew: האם קָרָאתָּ את הספר הזה כבר?
examples.translation: Have you already read this book?

examples.hebrew: קָרָאת את הספר הזה כבר?
examples.translation: Have you read this book already?

kara.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ק.ר.א relates to reading and calling. Note that 'קָרָא' can also mean 'he called'. Context determines the meaning.

idioms.usage: המורה ביקש מהתלמידים לקרוא בקול רם.
היושב ראש קרא לסדר בישיבה.

examples.hebrew: כשהייתי ילד, שַׁרְתִּי בכל הזדמנות.
examples.translation: When I was a child, I sang at every opportunity.

examples.hebrew: אתמול שַׁרְתָּ בקול נפלא בחתונה.
examples.translation: Yesterday you sang wonderfully at the wedding.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בבוקר שַׁרְתְּ בקול כל כך יפה.
examples.translation: Yesterday morning you sang so beautifully.

shir.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.י.ר is associated with singing and songs.

idioms.usage: הם שָׁרוּ שִׁיר הַלֵּל בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת.
הַשִּׁיר הַזֶּה נוֹתֵן לִי כֹּחַ בְּזְמַן קָשֶׁה.

hifil.note: Note: Different meaning, same spelling but different root ש-י-ר

shamar.rtm: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.hebrew: שָׁמַרְתִּי על הַבַּיִת כְּשֶׁהוּא הָיָה בַּמִּסע.
examples.translation: I guarded the house while he was on a trip.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה שָׁמַרְתָּ עַל הַבַּיִת בְּזְמַן שֶׁהָיִינוּ בַּחוּץ.
examples.translation: You guarded the house while we were out.

examples.hebrew: שָׁמַרְתְּ עַל הַבַּיִת כְּשֶׁהָיִיתִי בַּמִּסָּע.
examples.translation: You guarded the house when I was on the trip.

shamar.notes: Regular verb in Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root שׁ.מ.ר can mean 'to guard', 'to keep', or 'to observe', depending on context (e.g., guarding a place, keeping a secret, or observing rules). It’s widely used in both modern and biblical Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוא צָרִיךְ לִשְׁמוֹר עַל הַפֶּה שֶׁלּוֹ בַּפְּגִישׁוֹת. (He needs to watch his mouth in meetings.)

idioms.trl: one who guards their soul (cautious person)
idioms.usage: היא שׁוֹמֶרֶת נֶפֶשׁ וּמְנַסָּה לְהִמָּנַע מִסִּכּוּנִים. (She is cautious and tries to avoid risks.)

examples.hebrew: רַצְתִּי בַּחוֹף הַיָּם וְהִרְגָּשְׁתִּי חוֹפְשִׁי.
examples.translation: I ran on the beach and felt free.

examples.hebrew: בבוקר אתה רצת בפארק והיה לך כיף.
examples.translation: In the morning you ran in the park and it was fun for you.

examples.hebrew: רַצְתְּ מַהֵר לְהִגִּיעַ לַמּוֹעֵד
examples.translation: You ran quickly to get to the appointment.

ratz.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר.ו.צ is associated with running and rushing. Note the vowel changes and the presence of י during conjugation.

idioms.trl: spread quickly ('ran like fire in the field')
idioms.usage: הַשְּׁמוּעָה רָצְתָה כְּאֵשׁ בַּשָּׂדֶה.

idioms.trl: to go over songs quickly (to skim)
idioms.usage: הַמְנַצֵּחַ בִּיקֵּשׁ מֵהַמְּשׂוֹרֵר לָרוּץ עַל הַזִּמְרוֹת.

avad.rtm: Related to work, labor, or service

examples.hebrew: עָבַדְתִּי בחברה הזו במשך חמש שנים.
examples.translation: I worked in this company for five years.

examples.hebrew: עָבַדְתָּ קָשֶׁה בַּשָּׂדֶה הַיּוֹם
examples.translation: You worked hard in the field today.

examples.hebrew: עָבַדְתְּ קָשֶׁה בַּשָּׂדֶה אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: You worked hard in the field yesterday.

avad.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ע.ב.ד is associated with work, labor, and service.

idioms.usage: הנַגָּר עָבַד בְּיָדָיו לִיצוֹר אֶת הַשֻּׁלְחָן.
היא עוֹבֶדֶת שָׁעוֹת נוֹסָפוֹת בְּשָׁבוּעַ הַזֶּה.

examples.hebrew: אתמול שִׂחַקְתִּי עם הילדים בגינה.
examples.translation: Yesterday I played with the children in the park.

examples.hebrew: אתמול שִׂחַקְתָּ עם הילדים בגינה.
examples.translation: Yesterday you played with the children in the park.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בבוקר שִׂחַקְתְּ עם הילדים בגינה.
examples.translation: Yesterday morning you played with the children in the garden.

sichek.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל). The root ש.ח.ק is associated with playing, acting, and joking.

idioms.usage: היא שִׂחֲקָה אֶת הַתַּפְקִיד בִּצּוּרָה מְעוּלָה.
כֻּלָּנוּ מְשַׂחֲקִים בְּמִשְׂחַק הַחַיִּים.

examples.hebrew: אמש בחברת חברים צָחַקְתִּי עד דמעות.
examples.translation: Last night, in the company of friends, I laughed until tears.

examples.hebrew: אתמול צָחַקְתָּ כל כך חזק שכמעט נפלת מהכסא.
examples.translation: Yesterday you laughed so hard you nearly fell off your chair.

examples.hebrew: בפעם הראשונה שצָחַקְתְּ, הבנתי כמה את חשובה לי.
examples.translation: The first time you laughed, I realized how important you are to me.

tzachak.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root צ.ח.ק is associated with laughter and joy.
related_words: צַחְקָן (joker, someone who laughs a lot)

idioms.usage: הבדיחה הייתה כל כך מצחיקה שְׁצָחַקְנוּ עַד דְּמָעוֹת.
צְחוֹק הַגּוֹרָל, הִיא נִפְגְּשָׁה אִתּוֹ שׁוּב.

examples.hebrew: שָׁתִיתִי קפה הבוקר
examples.translation: I drank coffee this morning

examples.hebrew: שָׁתִיתָ את כל המים שבכוס.
examples.translation: You drank all the water in the glass.

examples.hebrew: אמש שָׁתִיתְ יותר מדי מים.
examples.translation: Last night you drank too much water.

shata.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.ת.ה is associated with drinking. Note the changes in the root letters during conjugation.

idioms.trl: drank the cup to the bottom (drained the cup)
idioms.usage: הוא שָׁתָה אֶת הַכּוֹס עַד הַתַּחְתִּית במסיבה.
בְּקַיִץ, הַיֶּלֶד שׁוֹתֶה כַּמַּיִם.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not used for this root.

examples.hebrew: רָאִיתִי את הַיָּם בַּבֹּקֶר
examples.translation: I saw the sea in the morning

examples.hebrew: רָאִיתָ את הַצִּפּוֹר בַּחֲצֵר?
examples.translation: Did you see the bird in the yard?

examples.hebrew: רָאִית את היופי שבשמיים?
examples.translation: Did you see the beauty in the sky?

ra'ah.notes: The verb 'לִרְאוֹת' is irregular in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר-א-ה involves weak letters, resulting in irregular conjugations, especially in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: לאחר שנים, הוא רָאָה אוֹר והבין את הטעות.

idioms.trl: only to look, not to touch
idioms.usage: הפָּסֶל זֶה לִרְאוֹת וְלֹא לִגְּעֹת.

nifal.note: Irregular forms due to weak root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Commonly used in the expression 'להתראות' (see you).

paal.rtm: Related to action, doing, or operation

examples.hebrew: במהלך היום, פָּעַלְתִּי בשקט כדי לשמור על ההפתעה.
examples.translation: During the day, I acted quietly to keep the surprise.

examples.hebrew: כשהבנת את חומרת המצב, פעלת במהירות וביעילות.
examples.translation: When you understood the severity of the situation, you acted quickly and efficiently.

examples.hebrew: את פעלת בתבונה כשבחרת ללכת לשם.
examples.translation: You acted wisely when you chose to go there.

paal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root פ.ע.ל is central in Hebrew and is associated with action and work. Interestingly, 'פָּעַל' is also the name of this verb pattern (binyan).

idioms.usage: היא פָּעֲלָה לְטוֹבַת הַקְּהִלָּה.
הוא פָּעַל בֵּינוֹ לְבֵין עַצְמוֹ בְּנֹשֵׂא זֶה.

examples.hebrew: אָכַלְתִּי אֲרוּחָה טָעִימָה בְּבֵית קָפֶה חָדָשׁ בָּעִיר.
examples.translation: I ate a delicious meal at a new cafe in the city.

examples.hebrew: אָכַלְתָּ את כל העוגה?
examples.translation: Did you eat all the cake?

examples.hebrew: אָכַלְתְּ אֲתָךְ בְּאֳכָלָה הַמְשׁוּלֶשֶׁת?
examples.translation: Did you eat your meal with a fork?

achal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.כ.ל is associated with eating and consumption. Note that in some forms, the initial א is silent in pronunciation.

idioms.trl: you messed up (literally: you ate her)
idioms.usage: אם לא תשקיע, אֲכַלְתָּ אוֹתָהּ במבחן.
ההרצאה הייתה אֹכֶל לְמַחְשָׁבָה.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

piel.note: Forms in Pi'el are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not commonly used for this root.

examples.hebrew: הָלַכְתִּי לְבֵית סֵפֶר בַּבֹּקֶר.
examples.translation: I went to school in the morning.

examples.hebrew: הָלַכְתָּ לַחֲנוּת בַּבֹּקֶר
examples.translation: You went to the store in the morning.

examples.hebrew: הָלַכְתְּ לַחֲנוּת אֶתְמוֹל?
examples.translation: Did you go to the store yesterday?

halach.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ה.ל.ך involves a third-letter weak root (the letter ך), resulting in irregular conjugations, especially in the future and imperative tenses.

idioms.usage: הפרויקט הוֹלֵךְ וּמִתְפַּתֵּחַ בצורה יפה.

idioms.trl: walked on the thin line (took a risk)
idioms.usage: הוא הָלַךְ עַל הַקָּוֵּה הַדָּק בהחלטתו.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not used for this root.

examples.hebrew: יָדַעְתִּי שֶׁאֲנִי צָרִיךְ לְהִתְקַדֵם בְּחַיַי.
examples.translation: I knew that I needed to move forward in my life.

examples.hebrew: כָּל-אֱלֹקים בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל, אֲנִי יָדַעְתָּ אֶת הָאֱלֹקים הַיְחִידִים.
examples.translation: I knew the one true G-d in Israel.

examples.hebrew: יָדַעְתְּ שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹהֵב אוֹתָךְ?
examples.translation: Did you know that I love you?

yada.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root י.ד.ע involves weak letters, resulting in some irregular conjugations, especially in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: הפילוסוף יָדַע שֶׁאֵין לוֹ יְדִיעָה מֻחְלֶטֶת.
מִי יוֹדֵעַ מָתַי נִפְגּוֹשׁ שׁוּב.

examples.hebrew: הֵבַנְתִּי לְבַסּוֹף אֶת הַמַּטָרָה שֶׁל הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.
examples.translation: I finally understood the purpose of the project.

examples.hebrew: כשהסברתי את התרגיל, האם הֵבַנְתָּ אותו?
examples.translation: When I explained the exercise, did you understand it?

examples.hebrew: כשסיפרתי לך את הסיפור, הֵבַנְתְּ את המסר?
examples.translation: When I told you the story, did you understand the message?

hevin.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל). The root ב.י.ן is associated with understanding and comprehension. 'לְהָבִין' is in the Hif'il binyan, which often indicates causative action.

idioms.usage: סליחה, אֵין לִי מֻשָּׂג מה התשובה.
החוֹקֵר הֵבִין דָּבָר מִתּוֹךְ דָּבָר.

examples.hebrew: אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁאֲנִי לֹא יְכוֹל לָבוֹא הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: I told him that I can't come today.

examples.hebrew: אָמַרְתָּ שֶׁתָּבוֹא מוֹכָרוֹן?
examples.translation: Did you say that you would come early?

examples.hebrew: אָמַרְתְּ לִי שֶׁאַתְּ בָּאָה לַחֲגוֹרָה.
examples.translation: You told me that you were coming to the party.

amar.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.מ.ר is associated with saying and speech. Note the irregular infinitive 'לוֹמַר'.

idioms.trl: say and do (follow words with actions)
idioms.usage: צריך אֱמֹר וְעֲשֵׂה, לא רק לדבר.

idioms.trl: whatever is said to you, do (be obedient)
idioms.usage: הוא למד שׁכָּל הָאֹמֵר לוֹ עֲשֵׂה.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are not commonly used for this root.

pual.note: Forms in Pu'al are not commonly used for this root.

hitpael.note: Forms in Hitpa'el are not commonly used for this root.

examples.hebrew: בָּאתִי לבקר את סבתא שלי בבית אבות.
examples.translation: I came to visit my grandmother in the nursing home.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שבָּאתָ לכאן, הכל השתנה.
examples.translation: After you came here, everything changed.

examples.hebrew: אַת בָּאת לַבֵּית בְּעֵת הַסְּעוּדָה.
examples.translation: You came home during dinner.

ba.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ב.ו.א is associated with coming and arriving. Note the irregular forms due to the presence of weak letters.

idioms.usage: סֵפֶר מְעַנְיֵן בָּא לְיָדַי.
הכַּעַס שֶׁלּוֹ בָּא לְבִיטּוּי בְּדִבּוּרָיו.

examples.hebrew: חָשַׁבְתִּי שֶׁאַתָּה לא באמת רוצה לעזור.
examples.translation: I thought you didn't really want to help.

examples.hebrew: חָשַׁבְתָּ שֶׁאֲנִי עוֹמֵד בַּתּוֹר עַל מִי?
examples.translation: Did you think I was standing in line for nothing?

examples.hebrew: חָשַׁבְתְּ שֶׁאֲנִי אֶפְגֹּשׁ אוֹתוֹ בַּמִּסְעָדָה?
examples.translation: Did you think I would meet him at the restaurant?

chashav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ח.ש.ב is associated with thinking and calculation. This root is also used in words related to computers (מַחְשֵׁב).

idioms.trl: thought carefully before acting (literally: counted to three)
idioms.usage: תמיד חָשַׁב עַד שְׁלוֹשָׁה לפני שהחליט.
כְּדַאי לְךָ לַחֲשֹׁב פַּעֲמַיִם לפני שאתה פועל.

examples.hebrew: אָהַבְתִּי לְהִתְהַלֵךְ בַּגַּן בְּבֹקֶר.
examples.translation: I loved to walk in the garden in the morning.

examples.hebrew: אָהַבְתָּ אוֹתָהּ מִיּוֹם שֶׁפָּגַשְׁתָּ אוֹתָהּ בַּפַּעַם הָרִאשׁוֹנָה.
examples.translation: You loved her from the day you first met her.

examples.hebrew: אָהַבְתְּ אוֹתוֹ מֵאֲזֶה יוֹם שֶׁפָּגַשְׁתְּ אוֹתוֹ.
examples.translation: You loved him since the day you met him.

ahav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root א.ה.ב is associated with love and affection. Note that in pronunciation, the initial א is often silent.

idioms.usage: זֶה הָיָה אַהֲבָה מִמַּבָּט רִאשׁוֹן.
הִיא אוֹהֶבֶת אֶת בְּנָהּ כָּמוֹתוֹ.

nifal.note: Forms in Nif'al are rarely used for this root.

examples.hebrew: רָצִיתִי לִנְסוֹעַ לַחוֹף, אֲבָל הָיָה יוֹתֵר מִדי עָמוס.
examples.translation: I wanted to go to the beach, but it was too crowded.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה רָצִיתָ לָלֶכֶת לַחוֹף אֶתְמוֹל, נָכוֹן?
examples.translation: You wanted to go to the beach yesterday, right?

examples.hebrew: אמש רָצִית לצאת לטיול בחוץ, אבל החלטת להישאר בבית.
examples.translation: Yesterday you wanted to go out for a walk, but you decided to stay home.

ratzah.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ר.צ.ה is associated with wanting and desiring. Note the changes in vowels in different conjugations due to the weak letter ה at the end of the root.

idioms.usage: כִּרְצוֹנְךָ, אֲנִי מוּכָן לְעֲזֹר.
הוא רָצָה בְּרָצוֹן לְהִתְנַדֵּב.

examples.hebrew: נָתַתִּי לוֹ אֶת הַסֵּפֶר שֶׁהוּא רָצָה.
examples.translation: I gave him the book he wanted.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה נָתַתָּ לִי אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: You gave me the key yesterday.

examples.hebrew: אִמָּא, נָתַתְּ לִי אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ?
examples.translation: Mom, did you give me the key?

natan.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root נ.ת.ן is associated with giving and providing. Note the irregular forms in the future and imperative due to the root letters.

idioms.usage: המנהל נָתַן חוֹפְשִׁי לַצָּוֶת לְיָצֵר.
תֵּן לִי יוֹם לַחְשֹׁב עַל זֶּה.

examples.hebrew: פָּגַשְׁתִּי אֶת חֲבֵרִי הַיָּשָׁן בַּקַּפֶה אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: I met my old friend at the cafe yesterday.

examples.hebrew: פָּגַשְׁתָּ את חברך הטוב בדרך הביתה?
examples.translation: Did you meet your good friend on your way home?

examples.hebrew: פָּגַשְׁתְּ אֶת חָבֵרַתִי הַיָּשָׁנָה בַּקְּנִיּוֹן אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: You met my old friend at the mall yesterday.

pagash.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root פ.ג.שׁ is associated with meeting or encountering.

idioms.usage: הם פָּגְשׁוּ פָּנִים אֶל פָּנִים לְרִאשׁוֹנָה.
הוא פָּגַשׁ אוֹתָהּ בְּמִקְרֶה בְּסוּפֶּר.

examples.hebrew: אמש יָשַׁנְתִּי שמונה שעות וחצי.
examples.translation: Last night I slept for eight and a half hours.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בלילה יָשַׁנְתָּ טוב?
examples.translation: Did you sleep well last night?

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ יָשַׁנְתְּ כָּל הַלַּיְלָה בְּלִי הַפְרָעָה.
examples.translation: You slept all night without interruption.

yashan.notes: Irregular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root י.ש.נ involves weak letters, resulting in irregular forms, especially in the future and imperative. The verb 'לִישׁוֹן' is commonly used to express sleeping.
related_words: יָשָׁן (old; different meaning when used as an adjective)

idioms.usage: המשקיע יָשֵׁן עַל זְהָב.
מַגִּיעַ הַזְּמַן לָלֶכֶת לִישׁוֹן.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁתַּמַּשְׁתִּי בַּמִּטְאַטֵא לְנַקּוֹת אֶת הַבַּיִת.
examples.translation: I used the broom to clean the house.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁתַּמַּשְׁתָּ בַּמַחְשֵׁב הַחָדָשׁ שֶׁלְּךָ?
examples.translation: Did you use your new computer?

examples.hebrew: איך השתמשת במכונת הכביסה בפעם הראשונה?
examples.translation: How did you use the washing machine for the first time?

hishtamesh.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates a reflexive or reciprocal action. The root ש.מ.ש relates to using or serving. 'להשתמש' means 'to use' in the sense of making use of something for a purpose.

idioms.usage: הוא הִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּהִזְדַּמְּנוּת לְלַמֵּד אוֹתָם.
לֹא טוֹב לְהִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּשֵׁם ה' לַשָּׁוְא.

examples.hebrew: כשהנכנסתי לבית, הבנתי ששכחתי את המפתחות.
examples.translation: When I entered the house, I realized I forgot the keys.

examples.hebrew: כשהנכנסת לחדר, כולם הסתובבו להסתכל עליך.
examples.translation: When you entered the room, everyone turned to look at you.

examples.hebrew: את נִכְנַסְתְּ הביתה בלי להתקשר קודם.
examples.translation: You entered the house without calling first.

niknas.notes: This verb is in binyan Nif'al (נִפְעַל), which often has a passive or reflexive meaning. The root כ.נ.ס relates to entering and gathering. 'להיכנס' means 'to enter' or 'to go in'.
related_words: הִכְנִיס (to insert, to bring in; Hif'il)

idioms.usage: הוא נִכְנַס לְתוֹךְ הָעִנְיָנִים וְהִבִּין אֶת הַמַּצָּב.
בוא נַחְלוֹק וְנִכָּנֵס לְחַדָּרִים.

examples.hebrew: הִסְבַּרְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁהַכִּתָּה בְּחֶדֶר מִסְפָּר שְׁלוֹשׁ.
examples.translation: I explained to him that the class is in room number three.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שהסברת את הנושא, הבנתי אותו טוב יותר.
examples.translation: After you explained the topic, I understood it better.

examples.hebrew: הִסְבַּרְתְּ לוֹ אֶת הַשִּׁיעוּר בְּצוֹרָה מְאוֹד בְּרוּרָה.
examples.translation: You explained the lesson to him very clearly.

hisbir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often expresses causative actions. The root ס.ב.ר is associated with reasoning and explanation.

idioms.usage: הוא הִסְבִּיר פָּנִים לָאוֹרְחִים.
הַמּוֹרֶה הִסְבִּיר לָנוּ אֶת הַמְּצֻפֶּה מִמֶּנּוּ.

examples.hebrew: הִרְגַּשְׁתִּי שמחה כשהגעתי לחוף הים.
examples.translation: I felt happy when I arrived at the beach.

examples.hebrew: הִרְגַּשְׁתָּ שִׁנּוּי בַּאֲוִירָה כְּשֶׁהִכְנַסְתָּ לַחֶדֶר?
examples.translation: Did you feel a change in the atmosphere when you entered the room?

examples.hebrew: הִרְגַּשְׁתְּ שֶׁמַּזְגָּה הַאֲוִיר הוֹלֵךְ וּמִתְחַמֵּם?
examples.translation: Did you feel that the weather is getting warmer?

hirgish.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), indicating causative action. The root ר.ג.ש relates to feeling and emotion. 'להרגיש' means 'to feel' or 'to sense'.

idioms.usage: הוא הִרְגִּישׁ בְּבַיִת בַּמָּקוֹם הֶחָדָשׁ.
אֲנִי מַרְגִּישׁ טוֹב הַיּוֹם.

examples.hebrew: בִּמְשךְ הַשָּׁנִים הִשְׁפַּעְתִּי עַל רַבִּים מִתְלַמִּידַי לִבחור בְּקָרִיירָה בְּתחום הַמדע.
examples.translation: Over the years, I influenced many of my students to choose a career in science.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁפַּעְתָּ עַל הַהַחְלָטָה בְּאוֹפֶן מִשְׁמָעוּתִי.
examples.translation: You significantly influenced the decision.

examples.hebrew: את הִשְׁפַּעְתְּ על ההחלטה שלי להתחיל ללמוד פסיכולוגיה.
examples.translation: You influenced my decision to start studying psychology.

hishpia.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ש-פ-ע relates to influence and abundance.

idioms.usage: התזונה הבריאה מַשְׁפִּיעָה טוֹב על הבריאות.
העישון מַשְׁפִּיעַ רַע על הריאות.

hitnaheg.rtm: Related to driving, leading, or behaving

examples.hebrew: הִתְנַהַגְתִּי בְּצוֹרָה מְכֻבֶּדֶת בַּמִּפְגָּשׁ.
examples.translation: I behaved respectfully at the meeting.

examples.hebrew: הִתְנַהַגְתָּ בצורה מכובדת מאוד אתמול.
examples.translation: You behaved very respectfully yesterday.

examples.hebrew: הִתְנַהַגְתְּ מוּפְתִית בַּמִפְגָשׁ הַמִשְׁפָּחְתִי.
examples.translation: You behaved exemplarily at the family meeting.

hitnaheg.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root נ-ה-ג is associated with driving, leading, or behaving. 'להתנהג' means 'to behave' or 'to conduct oneself'.

idioms.usage: הוא תמיד מִתְנַהֵג בְּיִשְׁרוּת.
אנא, הִתְנַהֲגוּ כָּרָאוּי בַּמִּפְגָּשׁ.

examples.hebrew: הֶאֱמַנְתִּי בוֹ מִיָד כְּשֶׁאָמַר אֶת הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה.
examples.translation: I believed him immediately when he said that thing.

examples.hebrew: הֶאֱמַנְתָּ לי כשהבטחתי לך שזה יקרה?
examples.translation: Did you believe me when I promised you this would happen?

examples.hebrew: הֶאֱמַנְתְּ שתוכלי לעשות את זה לבד?
examples.translation: Did you believe that you could do it alone?

leha'amin.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root א-מ-נ is associated with belief, faith, and trust. 'להאמין' means 'to believe' or 'to have faith'.

idioms.usage: הוא מַאֲמִין בְּעַצְמוֹ וּבְיְכוֹלוֹתָיו.
זֶה קָשֶׁה לְהַאֲמִין שֶׁהוּא עָשָׂה זֹאת.

examples.hebrew: הִכַּרְתִּי אותוֹ ברחוב והתחלנו לדבר.
examples.translation: I recognized him on the street and we started talking.

examples.hebrew: הִכַּרְתָּ את הדמות הזו מסרט אחר?
examples.translation: Did you recognize this character from another movie?

examples.hebrew: הִכַּרְתְּ אותוֹ ברחוב אמש?
examples.translation: Did you recognize him on the street last night?

lehakir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root נ-כ-ר is associated with recognition, acquaintance, and being foreign. 'להכיר' means 'to recognize', 'to know someone', or 'to be acquainted with'.

idioms.usage: הוא הִכִּיר בְּטָעוּתוֹ וּבִקֵּשׁ סְלִיחָה.
אֲנִי מַכִּיר טוֹבָה לְךָ עַל עֶזְרָתְךָ.

examples.hebrew: הִתְחַלְתִּי לִכְתוֹב אֶת הַמִּכְתָב אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: I started writing the letter yesterday.

examples.hebrew: הִתְחַלְתָּ לִרְקוֹד וְכֻלָּם הִצְטָרְפוּ אֵלֶיךָ.
examples.translation: You started dancing and everyone joined you.

examples.hebrew: הִתְחַלְתְּ לְלַמֵד אוֹתִי לִנְגֵן בְּגִיטָרָה.
examples.translation: You started teaching me how to play the guitar.

lehatkhil.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ת-ח-ל is associated with beginning or starting. 'להתחיל' means 'to start' or 'to begin' an action or process.

idioms.usage: הוא הִתְחִיל מֵהַתְּחִלָּה לִכְתֹּב אֶת הַסֵּפֶר.

idioms.trl: starting off on the right foot
idioms.usage: אֲנַחְנוּ מְקַוִּים לְהַתְחִיל בְּרֶגֶל יָמִין.

examples.hebrew: הִתְקַדַּמְתִּי בַּמִּשִׁימָה שֶׁלִּי הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: I progressed in my task today.

examples.hebrew: הִתְקַדַּמְתָּ בלימודי המתמטיקה שלך השנה.
examples.translation: You have progressed in your math studies this year.

examples.hebrew: הִתְקַדַּמְתְּ בַּמִּשִׁימָה בְּצוּרָה מְרַשִּׁימָה.
examples.translation: You have progressed impressively on the task.

lehitkadem.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpa'el (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal actions. The root ק-ד-ם is associated with advancing or moving forward. 'להתקדם' means 'to progress' or 'to advance' physically, professionally, or in other contexts.

idioms.usage: הַטֶּכְנוֹלוֹגְיָה הִתְקַדְּמָה בְּצַעֲדֵי עֲנָק.
לְאָן אֲנַחְנוּ מִתְקַדְּמִים בַּמִּשְׁתָּר?

examples.hebrew: הִפְסַקְתִּי לַעֲשׂוֹת אִתּוֹ שִׁיחוֹת מְאֻרְכּוֹת.
examples.translation: I stopped having long conversations with him.

examples.hebrew: הִפְסַקְתָּ לדבר באמצע המשפט.
examples.translation: You stopped talking in the middle of the sentence.

examples.hebrew: הִפְסַקְתְּ לְדַבֵּר בְּאֶמְצַע הַמִּשְׁפָּט.
examples.translation: You stopped talking in the middle of the sentence.

lehafsik.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root פ-ס-ק is associated with stopping or ceasing. 'להפסיק' means 'to stop' or 'to cease' an action. It can be used both transitively ('to stop something') and intransitively ('to stop').

idioms.usage: הַחוֹלֶה הִפְסִיק לְנְשׁוֹם וְהוּבַל לְבֵּית הַחוֹלִים.
הַקִּהִילָה הִפְסִיקָה אֶת הַמִּנְהָג הַיָּשָׁן.

paal.note: Common in legal or formal contexts

examples.hebrew: הִזְמַנְתִּי אֶת כָּל חֲבֵרַי לַמְּסִיבָה שֶׁלִּי.
examples.translation: I invited all my friends to my party.

examples.hebrew: הִזְמַנְתָּ אוֹתִי לְחַגִיגַת יוֹם הוּלֶדֶת שֶׁלְךָ?
examples.translation: Did you invite me to your birthday party?

examples.hebrew: הִזְמַנְתְּ אֶת כָּל הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה לְחַגִּיגַת יוֹם הוּלֶדֶת.
examples.translation: You invited the whole family to the birthday celebration.

lehazmin.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root ז-מ-נ is associated with invitation and ordering. 'להזמין' means 'to invite' someone or 'to order' something like food or products.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִזְמִין אֶת עַצְמוֹ לַמְּסִבָּה.
יֵשׁ לָכֶם הַזְמָנָה פְּתוּחָה לִבְקֹר בְּכָל זְמַן.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁאַרְתִּי לוֹ הוֹדָעָה בַּדֵּאוּרִית.
examples.translation: I left him a message on the answering machine.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁאַרְתָּ את המפתחות על השולחן.
examples.translation: You left the keys on the table.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁאַרְתְּ לי הודעה לפני שיצאת?
examples.translation: Did you leave me a message before you left?

lehash'ir.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל) and is used to express leaving something behind or retaining something. The root ש-א-ר is associated with remaining or leaving behind.
similar_verbs: לְהַנִּיחַ (lehaníach) - to put down, to leave

idioms.usage: הַמּוֹפָע הִשְׁאִיר רֹשֶׁם עָמוֹק.
הַסִּפְר הַזֶּה מַשְׁאִיר טַעַם שֶׁל עוֹד.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּעְתִּי לוֹ לְהִתְפַּעֵל מִמֻּזִיקָה חֲדָשָׁה.
examples.translation: I suggested to him to get inspired by new music.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּעְתָּ רַעְיוֹן מְעוֹלֶה בִּישִׁיבָה הַקוֹדֶמֶת.
examples.translation: You suggested an excellent idea at the last meeting.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּעְתְּ לָנוּ לְלֶכֶת לַחוֹף בְּשַׁבָּת.
examples.translation: You suggested to us to go to the beach on Saturday.

lehatzia.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root י-צ-ע is associated with proposing or offering. 'להציע' means 'to suggest', 'to propose', or 'to offer' something to someone.
similar_verbs: לְהוֹצִיעַ (lehotzí'a) - to bring out, to publish

idioms.usage: הוּא הִצִּיעַ לָהּ נִשּּׂוּאִין בַּחוֹפֶשׁ.
הִיא הִצִּיעָה לִי עֶזְרָה בַּפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

examples.hebrew: חִפַּשְׂתִּי את המפתחות בכל המגירות בבית.
examples.translation: I searched for the keys in all the drawers in the house.

examples.hebrew: חִפַּשְׂתָּ את המפתחות בכל הבית ולא מצאת אותם.
examples.translation: You searched for the keys all over the house and couldn't find them.

examples.hebrew: חִיפַּשְׂתְּ בַּכֻּלָּם אֲבָל לֹא מָצָאת אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ.
examples.translation: You searched through all of them but did not find the key.

lechapes.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root ח-פ-שׂ is associated with searching or seeking. 'לחפש' means 'to search' or 'to look for' something actively.

idioms.usage: הַבַּחוּר חִפֵּשׂ אֶת הַצָּמוּד בִּבְגָדִים.
אַל תִּהְיֶה מְחַפֵּשׂ אֶת הַצָּרָה.

pu'al.note: Less commonly used in modern Hebrew

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁלַמְתִּי את המטלה היום.
examples.translation: I completed the task today.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁלַמְתָּ את המשימה בזמן?
examples.translation: Did you complete the task on time?

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁלַמְתְּ אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקט בְּזְמַן שִׁיא.
examples.translation: You completed the project in record time.

lehashlim.notes: This verb is in binyan Hif'il (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates causative actions. The root שׁ-ל-מ is associated with wholeness and completion. 'להשלים' means 'to complete' or 'to finish' something.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשְׁלִים עִם הַמַּצָּב וְהִמְשִׁיךְ לַעֲבוֹד.
הַפְּרָטִים הַחֲדָשִׁים הִשְׁלִימוּ אֶת הַתְּמוּנָה.

nifal.note: Used to indicate something is being completed

lehavtiach.rtm: Related to promising, assuring, or making secure

examples.hebrew: הִבְטַחְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁאֲנִי אָבוֹא לַמְסִיבָה.
examples.translation: I promised him that I would come to the party.

examples.hebrew: הִבְטַחְתָּ שֶׁתָּבוֹא לַחֲגִיגָה וְלֹא הִגַּעְתָּ.
examples.translation: You promised you would come to the celebration and you didn't.

examples.hebrew: הִבְטַחְתְּ לִי שֶׁתָּבוֹאִי לַחֲגִיגָה.
examples.translation: You promised me that you would come to the celebration.

lehavtiach.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root ב-ט-ח relates to security or assurance, and 'לְהַבְטִיחַ' is transitive, often taking a direct object (what is promised) or לְ (le-, 'to') with an infinitive or recipient. Its Hif'il form and interpersonal commitment make it intermediate, distinct from simpler verbs like 'to say' (לְהַגִּיד).

idioms.trl: promised mountains of gold (made extravagant promises)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִבְטִיחַ הֲרֵי זָהָב אֲבָל לֹא קִיֵּם.

examples.hebrew: נִסִּיתִי לבשל אוכל אתיופי בפעם הראשונה.
examples.translation: I tried to cook Ethiopian food for the first time.

examples.hebrew: נִסִּיתָ לפתור את הבעיה לבד?
examples.translation: Did you try to solve the problem by yourself?

examples.hebrew: נִסִּיתְ לְהָכִין אֶת הַמֶּרֶק אֶתְמוֹל, אֲבָל לֹא הִצְלַחְתְּ.
examples.translation: You tried to make the soup yesterday, but you didn't succeed.

lenasot.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or repetitive action. The root נ-ס-ה is associated with trying or testing. 'לנסות' means 'to try' or 'to attempt' to do something.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִסָּה אֶת הַמַּזָּל בְּהַגְרָלָה.
תַּמְשִׁיךְ לְנַסּוֹת, וּלְבַסּוֹף תַּצְלִיחַ.

examples.hebrew: גִּילִּיתִי סוד מדהים בבית הישן הזה.
examples.translation: I discovered an amazing secret in this old house.

examples.hebrew: גִּילִּיתָ סוד שהיה חבוי שנים רבות.
examples.translation: You discovered a secret that was hidden for many years.

examples.hebrew: גילית את הסוד הגדול שלי.
examples.translation: You discovered my big secret.

legalot.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or intentional action. The root ג-ל-ה is associated with revealing, uncovering, or discovering. 'לגלות' means 'to discover' or 'to reveal' something that was previously hidden.

idioms.usage: הוּא לֹא גִּילָּה אֶת הַגַּלְגַּל, אֲבָל זֶה רַעֲיוֹן טוֹב.
הַמַּדְרִיךְ אָמַר שֶׁאֲנִי גִּילִּיתִי אֶת הָאֵשׁ.

examples.hebrew: בָּחַרְתִּי לָלֶכֶת לַחוֹף בְּיום שִׁישִׁי.
examples.translation: I chose to go to the beach on Friday.

examples.hebrew: בָּחַרְתָּ לָלֶכֶת לַחוֹף בְּיום שִׁישִׁי.
examples.translation: You chose to go to the beach on Friday.

examples.hebrew: בָּחַרְתְּ לָלֶכֶת לַחוֹף אֶתְמוֹל בַּבּוֹקֶר.
examples.translation: You chose to go to the beach yesterday morning.

livchor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active form. The root ב-ח-ר relates to choosing or selecting. 'לבחור' means 'to choose' or 'to select' something from among options.

idioms.usage: הוּא בָּחַר לַעֲשׂוֹת אֶת הַדָּבָר הַנָּכוֹן.
הִיא הִיא בְּחִירַת לִבּוֹ.

examples.hebrew: עָזַרְתִּי לוֹ לְהָרִים אֶת הַמִּשְׂאוֹת הַכְּבֵדִים.
examples.translation: I helped him lift the heavy weights.

examples.hebrew: בזמן שעברת את המבחן, עָזַרְתָּ לי להבין את החומר.
examples.translation: While you were passing the exam, you helped me understand the material.

examples.hebrew: את עָזַרְתְּ לי מאוד בשיעורי הבית.
examples.translation: You helped me a lot with the homework.

la'azor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the most common verb pattern in Hebrew. The root ע-ז-ר is associated with helping or assisting. 'לעזור' means 'to help' or 'to assist' someone in need.
related_words: עֶזוּר (ezúr) - region (note: different meaning but same root)

idioms.usage: הוּא עָזַר לְעַצְמוֹ לְהַשִּׂיג אֶת הַמַּטָּרָה.
לָמַדְתִּי קוּרְס בְּעֶזְרָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.

examples.hebrew: שָׁאַלְתִּי אֶת הַמּוֹרֶה אִם אֶפְשָׁר לְהַשְׁאִיל אֶת הַסֵּפֶר.
examples.translation: I asked the teacher if it was possible to borrow the book.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בבוקר שָׁאַלְתָּ אותי אם יש לי זמן לשתות קפה יחד.
examples.translation: Yesterday morning you asked me if I had time to have coffee together.

examples.hebrew: אמא, את שָׁאַלְתְּ את אבא אם אנחנו יכולים ללכת לחוף הים מחר?
examples.translation: Mom, did you ask Dad if we can go to the beach tomorrow?

lish'ol.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the simple active form. The root ש-א-ל is associated with asking or questioning. 'לשאול' means 'to ask' a question or to inquire about something.

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׁאַל בְּשָׁלוֹם חֲבֵרוֹ.
אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִשְׁאוֹל עַל הַדֶּרֶךְ.

nifal.note: Used less commonly in modern Hebrew

piel.note: In modern Hebrew, 'לשאול' in Pa'al can also mean 'to borrow,' though 'להשאיל' in Hif'il is more common for 'to lend.'

examples.hebrew: כשהייתי קטן, זָכַרְתִּי כל פרט מהסיפורים שסבתי סיפרה לי.
examples.translation: When I was little, I remembered every detail of the stories my grandmother told me.

examples.hebrew: זָכַרְתָּ אֶת הַיּוֹם הַהוּא שֶׁבִּלְיַתִי עִמְּךָ בַּחוֹף?
examples.translation: Do you remember that day we spent together at the beach?

examples.hebrew: זָכַרְתְּ אֶת הַיּוֹם שֶׁהָיִינוּ בַּחוֹף?
examples.translation: Did you remember the day we were at the beach?

lizkor.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active form. The root ז-כ-ר is associated with remembering and memory. 'לזכור' means 'to remember' or 'to recall' something.

idioms.usage: זְכֹר אֶת הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה לֵעָד.
הוּא זָכַר אוֹתָם לְטוֹב.

examples.hebrew: קָנִיתִי בַּיִת חָדָשׁ בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם.
examples.translation: I bought a new house in Jerusalem.

examples.hebrew: אבא, קָנִיתָ לי מתנה לחג?
examples.translation: Dad, did you buy me a gift for the holiday?

examples.hebrew: אתמול קָנִית לי חולצה חדשה.
examples.translation: Yesterday you bought me a new shirt.

liknot.notes: This is an irregular verb in the Pa'al (פָּעַל) binyan. The root ק.נ.ה is associated with acquiring or purchasing. The verb **לִקְנוֹת** is commonly used in everyday Hebrew when talking about buying items, whether small like groceries or big like houses.

idioms.trl: secured his place in the world
idioms.usage: בְּמַעֲשָׂיו הַטּוֹבִים, קָנָה אֶת עוֹלָמוֹ.
הוּא קָנָה אֶת הַמְּכוֹנִית בַּזּוֹל.

examples.hebrew: פָּתַחְתִּי את החלון כדי להכניס קצת אוויר צח.
examples.translation: I opened the window to let in some fresh air.

examples.hebrew: פָּתַחְתָּ את החלון לפני שהתחלנו לאכול.
examples.translation: You opened the window before we started eating.

examples.hebrew: פָּתַחְתְּ אֶת הַחֶלוֹן וְהַבַּיִת מִיָּד התמלא באוויר צח.
examples.translation: You opened the window and the house was immediately filled with fresh air.

liftoach.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), which is the basic active pattern in Hebrew. The root פ-ת-ח is associated with opening and beginning. 'לפתוח' means 'to open' physical objects like doors, books, or metaphorically, to start something new.

idioms.usage: הוּא פָּתַח דַּף חָדָשׁ בְּקָרֵיירָה שֶׁלּוֹ.
הַסִּפְר פָּתַח לִי אֶת הָעֵינַיִם.

examples.hebrew: סִפַּרְתִּי לוֹ עַל הַמַּסָּע שֶׁלִי לְאֵירוֹפָּה.
examples.translation: I told him about my trip to Europe.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה סִפַּרְתָּ לִי אֶת הַסִּפּוּר הַזֶּה כְּבָר?
examples.translation: Did you already tell me this story?

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ סִפַּרְתְּ לִי אֶת הַסִּפּוּר הַכִּי מְעַנְיֵן שֶׁשָּׁמַעְתִּי מֵעוֹלָם.
examples.translation: You told me the most interesting story I have ever heard.

lesaper.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or iterative action. The root ס-פ-ר is associated with recounting, telling, or counting. 'לספר' means 'to tell' a story or an account of something.

idioms.usage: הוּא סִיפֵּר לֹא חָדֶג לַאֲבוֹת.
בְּכיתה, הוּא סִיפֵּר מַעֲשָׂה עַל הָעִיר.

ledamot.rtm: Related to imagining, resembling, or likening

examples.hebrew: בלילה שעבר דִּמִּיתִי שאני מטייל בחלל.
examples.translation: Last night I imagined that I was traveling through space.

examples.hebrew: דִּמִּיתָ שֶׁאֲנִי יְכוֹלָה לִקְרוֹא אֶת מַחֲשָׁבוֹתֶיךָ?
examples.translation: Did you imagine that I could read your thoughts?

examples.hebrew: כשהייתי ילד, דמיתי לעצמי שיש לי כוחות על.
examples.translation: As a child, I imagined to myself that I had superpowers.

ledamot.notes: This verb is in the Piel binyan (פִּעֵל), often used for intensive or causative actions. The root ד-מ-ה relates to imagining or resembling, and 'לְדַמּוֹת' is transitive in Piel, requiring a direct object (what is imagined), often marked with אֶת (et). Its cognitive nature and Piel structure make it intermediate, distinct from simpler Pa'al verbs.

idioms.trl: imagined a figure in his heart (envisioned deeply)
idioms.usage: הוּא דִּמָּה דְּמוּת בְּלִבּוֹ שֶׁל עֹלָם מֻשְׁלָם.

lehachin.rtm: Related to preparing, establishing, or making ready

examples.hebrew: הֵכַנְתִּי אֲרוּחָה טְעִימָה לַמִּשְׁפָּחָה.
examples.translation: I prepared a delicious meal for the family.

examples.hebrew: הֵכַנְתָּ אֲרוּחָה טְעִימָה מְאוֹד לְשַׁבָּת.
examples.translation: You prepared a very tasty meal for Shabbat.

examples.hebrew: הֵכַנְתְּ אֲרוּחָה מְעוּלָה לְכָל הַמִשְפָּחָה.
examples.translation: You prepared an excellent meal for the whole family.

lehachin.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root כ-ו-ן relates to establishing or preparing, and 'לְהָכִין' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is prepared), often with אֶת (et). It can also take לְ (le-, 'for') to indicate purpose or recipient. Its Hif'il form, causative sense, and everyday utility make it intermediate.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵכִין אֶת הַשְּׁטָח לַשִּׂיחָה הַקָּשָׁה.

lehamtsia.rtm: Related to inventing, finding, or creating

examples.hebrew: הִמְצֵאתִי מַכְשִׁיר חָדָשׁ שֶׁיָּכוֹל לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת הָעוֹלָם.
examples.translation: I invented a new device that can change the world.

examples.hebrew: הִמְצֵאתָ מִכְשִׁיר חָדָשׁ שֶׁמְשַׁנֶּה אֶת הַחַיִּים?
examples.translation: Did you invent a new device that changes lives?

examples.hebrew: הִמְצֵאת מִכְשִׁיר חָדָשׁ שֶׁמְּאַפְשֵׁר לִתְקוֹרֵר בְּלִי חַשְׁמַל.
examples.translation: You invented a new device that allows cooling without electricity.

lehamtsia.notes: This verb is in the Hif'il binyan (הִפְעִיל), typically used for causative actions. The root מ-צ-א relates to finding or creating, and 'לְהַמְצִיא' is transitive, requiring a direct object (what is invented), often with אֶת (et), though it can omit it in informal use. It can also mean 'to make up' (e.g., a story). Its Hif'il form and creative nuance make it intermediate.
similar_verbs: לְתַקֵּן (letaken) - to repair (in a constructive sense)

idioms.trl: invented the wheel (did something obvious or redundant)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִמְצִיא אֶת הַגַּלְגַּל כְּשֶׁהִצִּיעַ פִּתְרוֹן יָדוּעַ.

examples.hebrew: נָסַעְתִּי לַחוּץ לָאָרֶץ לִפְגֹשׁ אֶת הַמִשׁפָחָה שֶלִּי.
examples.translation: I traveled abroad to meet my family.

examples.hebrew: כשהיית קטן, נָסַעְתָּ לחו"ל עם ההורים שלך?
examples.translation: When you were little, did you travel abroad with your parents?

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ נָסַעְתְּ לְחוּץ לָאָרֶץ בְּשָׁנָה שֶׁעָבְרָה?
examples.translation: Did you travel abroad last year?

nasoa.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root נ.ס.ע is associated with movement, traveling, or driving.

idioms.usage: אֲנִי אוֹהֵב לִנְסוֹעַ בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְלִרְאוֹת אֶת הַנּוֹף.

idioms.trl: traveled to the world (euphemism for passing away)
idioms.usage: סָבִי נָסַע לְעוֹלָם לִפְנֵי שְׁלוֹשִׁים שָׁנָה.

examples.hebrew: בָּנִיתִי בַּיִת חָדָשׁ בַּשָּׁנָה שֶׁעָבְרָה.
examples.translation: I built a new house last year.

examples.hebrew: אתה בָּנִיתָ את הבית הזה בידיים שלך?
examples.translation: Did you build this house with your own hands?

examples.hebrew: היא בָּנִית בית חדש בשנה שעברה.
examples.translation: She built a new house last year.

banah.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ב.נ.ה is associated with building and construction, both physically and metaphorically (e.g., building a family or future).

idioms.usage: הֵם רוֹצִים לִבְנוֹת עָתִיד טוֹב לִילָדֵיהֶם.

idioms.trl: built a tower in the air (castles in the sky)
idioms.usage: אַל תִּבְנֶה מִגְדָּל בָּאֲוִיר, תִּהְיֶה מַמָּשִׁי!

mng: to be caused to be built

dayen.rtm: Related to judging, discussing, or debating

examples.hebrew: אַחֲרֵי שֶׁדִּיַּנְתִּי אִתָּךְ, הָבַנְתִּי אֶת הַנֹּקֶבֶת.
examples.translation: After I discussed with you, I understood the issue.

examples.hebrew: אתמול דִּיַּנְתָּ עם החברים על הנושא החדש.
examples.translation: Yesterday you discussed the new topic with your friends.

examples.hebrew: בפגישה האחרונה דִּיַּנְתְּ עם חברייך על הנושא הזה.
examples.translation: In the last meeting, you discussed this topic with your friends.

dayen.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root ד.י.ן relates to judging or debating, and לְדַיֵּן can mean 'to discuss,' 'to debate,' or 'to judge' depending on context, with 'discuss' being common in modern conversational Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הֵם דִּיְּנוּ עַל כָּל דָּבָר בְּפַגִּישָׁה אַחַת.

examples.hebrew: שִׁתַּפְתִּי עִם כֻּלָּם אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת הַטּוֹבוֹת.
examples.translation: I shared the good news with everyone.

examples.hebrew: אתמול שִׁתַּפְתָּ איתי את הסוד הכי גדול שלך.
examples.translation: Yesterday you shared your biggest secret with me.

examples.hebrew: אתמול שִׁתַּפְתְּ איתי את הסוד הכי גדול שלך.
examples.translation: Yesterday you shared your biggest secret with me.

shatef.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or causative action. The root שׁ.ת.ף relates to partnership or collaboration, and לְשַׁתֵּף can mean 'to share' (e.g., information, feelings), 'to involve' (e.g., in a process), or 'to collaborate' depending on context.

idioms.usage: הַצּוֹוֶת שִׁתֵּף פְּעוּלָה לְהַצִּיל אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

examples.hebrew: הַחֲלָטִים שִׁנִּיתִי אֶת דַּעְתִּי לְגַבֵּי הַמַּצָב.
examples.translation: I have changed my mind about the situation.

examples.hebrew: שִׁנִּיתָ את דעתך בנוגע לנסיעה?
examples.translation: Did you change your mind about the trip?

examples.hebrew: אתמול שִׁנִּית את דעתך בנוגע לחופשה.
examples.translation: Yesterday you changed your mind about the vacation.

shanot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root שׁ.נ.ה relates to change or repetition (also linked to 'shana,' year), and לְשַׁנּוֹת is used for both tangible (e.g., objects) and intangible (e.g., opinions) changes.

idioms.usage: הוּא שִׁנָּה אֶת עוֹרוֹ וְהָיָה לְאָדָם טוֹב יוֹתֵר.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּלְתִּי את הַיֶּלֶד מִן הַמַּיִם.
examples.translation: I saved the child from the water.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּלְתָּ אוֹתִי מִמְּצוּקָה גְדוֹלָה
examples.translation: You saved me from great distress.

examples.hebrew: הִצַּלְתְּ את הילד מטביעה בבריכה.
examples.translation: You saved the child from drowning in the pool.

hatzil.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action. The root נ.צ.ל relates to rescue or deliverance, and לְהַצִּיל is used for both physical (e.g., saving a life) and abstract (e.g., saving a situation) contexts.

idioms.trl: saved in the nick of time
idioms.usage: הוּא הִצִּיל אֶת הַמַּצָּב בְּעוֹד מוֹעֵד.

examples.hebrew: הִסְכַּמְתִּי לבוא לפגישה מחר בבוקר.
examples.translation: I agreed to come to the meeting tomorrow morning.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שדיברנו, הִסְכַּמְתָּ לבוא למסיבה.
examples.translation: After we talked, you agreed to come to the party.

examples.hebrew: הִסְכַּמְתְּ לבוא למסיבה הלילה?
examples.translation: Did you agree to come to the party tonight?

haskim.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative or active action. The root ס.כ.ם relates to agreement or consent, and לְהַסְכִּים is typically followed by לְ (le-, 'to') or עַל (al, 'on/about') to indicate what is agreed upon.

idioms.usage: הִיא הִסְכִּימָה בְּלֵב שָׁלֵם לָעֲזוֹר לָנוּ.

examples.hebrew: עָנִיתִי לוֹ בִּמְהִירוּת כְּשֶׁשָּׁאַל אוֹתִי שְׁאֵלָה.
examples.translation: I answered him quickly when he asked me a question.

examples.hebrew: כשהצלצלתי אליך אתמול, עָנִיתָ במהירות.
examples.translation: When I called you yesterday, you answered quickly.

examples.hebrew: הִיא עָנִית לִי בְּחִיּוּךְ כְּשֶׁשָּׁאַלְתִּי אוֹתָהּ אִם הִיא בְּסֵדֶר.
examples.translation: She answered me with a smile when I asked her if she was okay.

anot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), though the guttural ע affects vowel patterns (e.g., עוֹנֶה instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ע.נ.ה relates to answering or responding, and לַעֲנוֹת is often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate the recipient or context of the response.

idioms.trl: answered with a small head (answered modestly)
idioms.usage: הוּא עָנָה בְּרֹאשׁ קָטָן כְּשֶׁשָּׁאֲלוּ אוֹתוֹ עַל הַזֹּאת.

examples.hebrew: יָצַרְתִּי קְעָרָה מִקֶרָמִיקָה.
examples.translation: I created a ceramic bowl.

examples.hebrew: יָצַרְתָּ אוֹתָהּ בִּדְמוּת אֱלֹקים
examples.translation: You created her in the image of G-d.

examples.hebrew: כְּשֶׁיָצַרְתְּ אֶת הַפְּסָל הַזֶּה, רָאִיתִי אֶת הַכִּשָּׁרוֹן שֶׁבָּךְ.
examples.translation: When you created this sculpture, I saw the talent in you.

tzor.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural צ slightly influencing vowel patterns (e.g., יוֹצֵר). The root י.צ.ר relates to creating or forming, and לִיצוֹר is used for artistic, practical, or conceptual creation, often implying an active process.

idioms.usage: הוּא יָצַר אֶת הָעֵסֶק מֵהָאֵפֶס בְּיָדָיו.

examples.hebrew: הִצְטָרַפְתִּי לקבוצה של חברים וטיילנו ברחבי הארץ.
examples.translation: I joined a group of friends and we traveled around the country.

examples.hebrew: הִצְטָרַפְתָּ לַקְבּוּצָה בַּשָּׁבוּעַ שֶׁעָבַר?
examples.translation: Did you join the group last week?

examples.hebrew: הִצְטָרַפְתְּ לקבוצת הריצה שלנו בשבוע שעבר?
examples.translation: Did you join our running group last week?

hitztaref.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action, here suggesting joining oneself to something or someone. The root צ.ר.ף relates to combining or attaching, and לְהִצְטָרֵף is typically followed by לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate what is being joined.

idioms.trl: joined the fray (joined the effort or fight)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִצְטָרֵף לַמַּעֲרָכָה לְשַׁפֵּר אֶת הַמַּצָּב.

akov.rtm: Related to following, tracking, or pursuing

examples.hebrew: עָקַבְתִּי אַחֲרֵי הַמַּפֶּה בַּמִּדְבָּר.
examples.translation: I followed the map in the desert.

examples.hebrew: עָקַבְתָּ אַחֲרֵי הַסִּפּוּר הַזֶּה בְּכָל הָרֶשֶׁת.
examples.translation: You followed this story all over the web.

examples.hebrew: עָקַבְתְּ אַחֲרֵי הַסִּפּוּר מֵאֲזֵה שֶׁשִּׁנִּיָה.
examples.translation: You followed the story since second grade.

akov.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ע affecting vowel patterns (e.g., עוֹקֵב instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ע.ק.ב relates to following or tracking, and לַעֲקֹב is often followed by אַחֲרֵי (acharei, 'after') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate what is being followed.

idioms.usage: הוּא עָקַב אַחֲרֵיהָ מִן הַצֵּל כְּדֵי לֹא לְהֵרָאוֹת.

examples.hebrew: הוֹבַלְתִּי אֶת הַקְּבוּצָה לְנִצָּחוֹן בְּמִשְׁחָק הַכַּדוּרְסַל.
examples.translation: I led the team to victory in the basketball game.

examples.hebrew: הוֹבַלְתָּ אֶת הַקְּבוּצָה לְנִצָּחוֹן מְדְהִים.
examples.translation: You led the team to an amazing victory.

examples.hebrew: הוֹבַלְתְּ אוֹתָנוּ בְּדֶרֶךְ הַיָּשָׁר.
examples.translation: You led us on the right path.

hovil.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause others to follow or to guide. The root י.ב.ל (often appearing as ה.ב.ל in Hifil) relates to leading or bringing, and לְהוֹבִיל can be used literally (e.g., guiding people) or figuratively (e.g., leading a project).
similar_verbs: לִנְהוֹג (linhoG) - to lead (e.g., a vehicle or group)

idioms.trl: led at the head of the camp (took the forefront)
idioms.usage: הוּא הוֹבִיל בְּרֹאשׁ הַמַּחֲנֶה לְשֵׁנוּי חֶבְרָתִי.

examples.hebrew: הָגַנְתִּי עַל הַיְלָדִים מִפְּנֵי הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ הַחֲזָקָה.
examples.translation: I protected the children from the strong sun.

examples.hebrew: הָגַנְתָּ עַל הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה בִּזְמַן הַסַּעַר.
examples.translation: You protected the family during the storm.

examples.hebrew: הָגַנְתְּ עלינו מפני הסכנה בלילה.
examples.translation: You protected us from the danger at night.

hagen.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause protection or defense. The root ג.נ.ן relates to guarding or shielding, and לְהָגֵן is typically followed by עַל (al, 'on/over') to indicate what is being protected.
related_words: גַּנָּן (ganan) - gardener (related root, protector of a garden)

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵגֵן בְּגוּפוֹ עַל הַיְּלָדִים בִּזְמַן הַסַּכָּנָה.

hodia.rtm: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.hebrew: הוֹדַעְתִּי לְכֻלָּם שֶׁאֲנִי בָּא לַמְּסִבָּה.
examples.translation: I informed everyone that I am coming to the party.

examples.hebrew: הוֹדַעְתָּ לְכֻלָּם עַל הַשִׁינּוּי בַּתָּכְנִית.
examples.translation: You informed everyone about the change in the plan.

examples.hebrew: הוֹדַעַתְּ לוֹ אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת בְּעִדּוּן רַב.
examples.translation: You informed him of the news with great delicacy.

hodia.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to know' into 'to cause to know' or 'to inform'. It’s one of the most common forms for this root in modern Hebrew, widely used for notifying or reporting, contrasting with Pi’el’s less frequent 'to inform' (יִדֵּעַ).

idioms.usage: הוּא הוֹדִיעַ בְּרֹאשׁ חָדָשׁ עַל הַתָּכְנִית הַחֲדָשָׁה. (He informed with a fresh start about the new plan.)

mng: to be caused to be known

examples.hebrew: בַּמִּסִבָּה הִשְׁתַּתַּפְתִּי בְּכַמָּה מִשְׂחָקִים.
examples.translation: At the party, I participated in several games.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁתַּתַּפְתָּ בַּתְּכַנִּית הַזוֹ?
examples.translation: Did you participate in this program?

examples.hebrew: את הִשְׁתַּתַּפְתְּ בפעילות ההתנדבות אתמול?
examples.translation: Did you participate in the volunteer activity yesterday?

hishtatef.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action, here suggesting involving oneself in an activity or group. The root שׁ.ת.ף relates to sharing or partnership, and לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף is typically followed by בְּ (be-, 'in') to indicate what is being participated in.

idioms.usage: הִיא הִשְׁתַּתְּפָה בְּשִׂמְחָה בַּחֲתוּנָה שֶׁלָּהֶם.

examples.hebrew: חָגַגְתִּי אֶת יוֹם הוּלֶדֶת בִּתִּי בַּשָּׁבוּעַ שֶׁעָבַר.
examples.translation: I celebrated my daughter's birthday last week.

examples.hebrew: איך חָגַגְתָּ את יום הולדתך?
examples.translation: How did you celebrate your birthday?

examples.hebrew: חָגַגְתְּ אֶת יוֹם הוּלֶדֶת בַּת שְׁלוֹשׁ עִם מִשְׁפָּחָה וְחֲבֵרִים.
examples.translation: You celebrated your daughter's third birthday with family and friends.

chagot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ח affecting vowel patterns (e.g., חוֹגֵג instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ח.ג.ה relates to festivity or holidays, and לְחַגּוֹת is often used specifically for observing holidays or special occasions, distinguishing it slightly from לְחַגֵּג (Piel), which has a broader celebratory connotation.

idioms.trl: celebrated the holiday as it should be
idioms.usage: הֵם חָגְגוּ אֶת הַחַג כָּרָאוּי עִם תְּפִלּוֹת וְסְעוּדוֹת.

examples.hebrew: דָּמִיתִי אֶת עַצְמִי מְטַיֵּל בַּחוֹף הַיָּם.
examples.translation: I imagined myself walking on the beach.

examples.hebrew: במהלך הלילה דָּמִיתָ אותי כמישהו אחר.
examples.translation: During the night you imagined me as someone else.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה דָּמִיתָ אוֹתִי כְּמִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְסוּגָּל לְהָבִין.
examples.translation: You imagined me as someone who is not capable of understanding.

damot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with no guttural influences complicating its conjugation. The root ד.מ.ה relates to likeness or resemblance, and לְדַמּוֹת often means to picture something in the mind or liken one thing to another. It’s typically followed by אֵיךְ (eich, 'how') or אֶת (et) to specify what is being imagined.

idioms.usage: הוּא דָּמָה בְּדִמְיוֹנוֹ אֶת הָעֹלָם הַמּוּשְׁלָם.

examples.hebrew: אָסַפְתִּי פֵּרוֹת מִן הַגִּנָּה בַּבֹּקֶר.
examples.translation: I collected fruits from the garden in the morning.

examples.hebrew: אָסַפְתָּ את כל הדברים החשובים לפני שיצאת לדרך.
examples.translation: You collected all the important things before you left.

examples.hebrew: אָסַפְתְּ אֶת כָּל הַפְּרָחִים בַּשָּׂדֶה.
examples.translation: You collected all the flowers in the field.

esof.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural א affecting vowel patterns (e.g., אוֹסֵף). The root א.ס.ף relates to gathering or collecting, and לֶאֱסוֹף is often followed by אֶת (et) to indicate what is being collected, or used with מֵ (me-, 'from') to specify the source.

idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי הַפְּרֵידָה, הִיא אָסְפָה אֶת הַשְּׁבָרִים וְהִתְחִילָה מֵחָדָשׁ.

examples.hebrew: אמש חָלַמְתִּי על טיול ביערות אירופה.
examples.translation: Last night I dreamt of a trip through the forests of Europe.

examples.hebrew: חָלַמְתָּ שֶׁאֲנִי מְדַבֵּר אִתְּךָ בְּאֵיזֶה לַיְלָה?
examples.translation: Did you dream that I was talking to you one night?

examples.hebrew: חָלַמְתְּ אֶת הַחֲלוֹם הַזֶּה כבר פעמיים בשבוע האחרון.
examples.translation: You have dreamed this dream twice already in the past week.

chalom.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ח affecting vowel patterns (e.g., חוֹלֵם). The root ח.ל.ם relates to dreaming, either in sleep or as an aspiration, and לַחֲלוֹם is often followed by עַל (al, 'about') to specify the content of the dream.

idioms.usage: הוּא חָלַם בְּעֵרֶב עַל הַזֹּאת בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל הַיּוֹם.

examples.hebrew: הֵאַרְתִּי את החדר בנרות כדי ליצור אווירה רומנטית.
examples.translation: I illuminated the room with candles to create a romantic atmosphere.

examples.hebrew: הֵאַרְתָּ את היום שלי בחיוך שלך.
examples.translation: You brightened my day with your smile.

examples.hebrew: אַת הֵאַרְתְּ אֶת הַחֶדֶר בְּחִיּוּךְ שֶׁלָּךְ.
examples.translation: You lit up the room with your smile.

ha’ir.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause light to shine or to illuminate. The root א.ו.ר relates to light, and לְהָאִיר can be used literally (e.g., to light up) or figuratively (e.g., to enlighten). It’s often followed by אֶת (et) with an object or עַל (al, 'on') to specify what is illuminated.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵאִיר פָּנִים כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת.

examples.hebrew: מָכַרְתִּי אֶת הַבַּיִת שֶׁלִּי בַּשָּׁנָה שְׁעָבְרָה.
examples.translation: I sold my house last year.

examples.hebrew: מָכַרְתָּ את המכונית שלך בשבוע שעבר?
examples.translation: Did you sell your car last week?

examples.hebrew: את מָכַרְתְּ את הדירה שלך בירושלים בשנה שעברה?
examples.translation: Did you sell your apartment in Jerusalem last year?

machar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root מ.כ.ר is associated with selling or commerce. It's a common verb used in everyday Hebrew when talking about selling items, services, or even abstract concepts like selling an idea.
similar_verbs: לְמַכֵּר (lemaker) - to market, to sell extensively

idioms.usage: הוּא מָכַר אֶת נַפְשׁוֹ בִּשְׁבִיל כֶּסֶף.
הוּא מָכַר לִי סַפִּירוֹת וְלֹא קִיֵּם.

examples.hebrew: תֵּאַרְתִּי לוֹ אֶת הַמַּקוֹם בְּפִרוּט.
examples.translation: I described the place to him in detail.

examples.hebrew: תֵּאַרְתָּ את המקום בצורה מדהימה.
examples.translation: You described the place in an amazing way.

examples.hebrew: תֵּאַרְתְּ את החוויה בצורה מרתקת.
examples.translation: You described the experience in a fascinating way.

taar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or causative action. The root ת.א.ר is associated with forms and descriptions. לְתָאֵר is used when providing details or explanations about something.

idioms.usage: תֵּאֵר לְךָ מָה יָכוֹל לִקְרוֹת.

examples.hebrew: הֵבֵאתִי לך את הדברים שביקשת.
examples.translation: I brought you the things you asked for.

examples.hebrew: הֵבֵאתָ אִתְּךָ אֶת הַסֵּפֶר שֶׁבִּקֵּשְׁתִּי?
examples.translation: Did you bring the book I asked for?

examples.hebrew: הֵבֵאת לִי אֶת הַסֵּפֶר שֶׁהִזְמַנְתִּי בָּאִינְטֶרְנֶט?
examples.translation: Did you bring me the book I ordered online?

lehavi.notes: The verb **להביא** (*lehavi*) is a regular verb in binyan **Hif'il** (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action. Here, it means 'to cause to come,' i.e., to bring. The root letters ב.ו.א generally relate to 'coming' or 'entering' (as in the verb **לָבוֹא** - 'to come'). **להביא** is commonly used in daily speech for bringing objects, people, or even abstract concepts.

idioms.trl: brought him up to here (to this point)
idioms.usage: הַנִּסָּיוֹן הֵבִיא אוֹתוֹ עַד הֲלֹם.
הוּא הֵבִיא עַל עַצְמוֹ אֶת הַצָּרוֹת.

examples.hebrew: בִּקַּרְתִּי אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים בַּיִתָם בַּשַּׁבָּת.
examples.translation: I visited my friends at their home on Saturday.

examples.hebrew: בִּקַּרְתָּ אֶת הַמּוּזֶאוֹן בְּתֵל אָבִיב?
examples.translation: Did you visit the museum in Tel Aviv?

examples.hebrew: בִּקַּרְתְּ אֶת סָבְתָּךְ בְּבֵית אֲבוֹת אַחֲרֵי הַחֲגִים.
examples.translation: You visited your grandmother in a nursing home after the holidays.

levaker.notes: The verb **לְבַקֵּר** (*levaker*) is a regular verb in the **Piel** (פִּעֵל) binyan, which often indicates an intensive or frequentative action. The root ב.ק.ר is associated with visiting, inspecting, or criticizing. In everyday Hebrew, **לְבַקֵּר** is commonly used to talk about visiting places or people. It can also mean 'to criticize' in a different context.

idioms.usage: הַנָּשִׂיא בִּקֵּר פְּנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ.
הַסּוֹפֵר בִּקֵּר בַּחֲמָה בּוּשֶׁם אֶת הַסֵּפֶר הֶחָדָשׁ.

examples.hebrew: לָכַתִּי בַּפָּארק אֶתְמוֹל עִם הַכֶּלֶב שֶׁלִּי.
examples.translation: I walked in the park yesterday with my dog.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה לָכַתָּ אֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ הַזּוֹ כְּבָר הַרְבֵּה פְּעָמִים.
examples.translation: You have walked this path many times already.

examples.hebrew: היא לָכַתְּ בַּשְּׁבִיל עַד הַבַּיִת.
examples.translation: She walked along the path until she reached the house.

lalechet.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ל-כ-ת overlaps with 'halach' (הָלַךְ), but 'laléchet' emphasizes the act of walking. The present tense uses forms of 'holech' (הוֹלֵךְ), which is more common in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוּא בָּחַר לָלֶכֶת בְּדַרְכּוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו.
אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ 'לֵךְ לְךָ' כְּשֶׁהִתְרַגַּזְתִּי.

litzpot.rtm: Related to watching, observing, or expecting

examples.hebrew: צָפִיתִי בסרט מצוין אתמול בערב.
examples.translation: I watched an excellent movie last night.

examples.hebrew: צָפִיתָ בסרט הזה אתמול בערב?
examples.translation: Did you watch this movie last night?

examples.hebrew: היא צָפִית בסרט אתמול בערב.
examples.translation: She watched a movie last night.

litzpot.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root צ-פ-ה relates to watching or expecting. In modern Hebrew, 'litzpot' is commonly used for watching (e.g., TV) and expecting (e.g., an event).

idioms.usage: הוּא עָמַד כְּצוֹפֶה מִן הַצַּד בִּמְקוֹם לְעַזּוֹר.
אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִצְפּוֹת לְעָתִיד טוֹב יוֹתֵר.

linhog.rtm: Related to driving, leading, or guiding

examples.hebrew: בשבוע שעבר נהגתי ברכב של אבא שלי.
examples.translation: Last week I drove my father's car.

examples.hebrew: נָהַגְתָּ בזהירות כשהיית בדרך לבית הספר.
examples.translation: You drove carefully on your way to school.

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ נָהַגְתְּ בַּמְּכוֹנִית הַחֲדָשָׁה שֶׁלִּי אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.translation: You drove my new car yesterday.

linhog.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root נ-ה-ג relates to driving or leading, with modern usage focused on driving vehicles. It can also mean 'to behave' in different contexts, but 'to drive' is primary here. The guttural ה affects pronunciation.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּמִיד נוֹהֵג בְּזָהִירוּת בַּדְּרָכִים.

idioms.trl: to drive with a soft hand (lead gently)
idioms.usage: הַמְּנַהֵל צָרִיךְ לִנְהוֹג בְּיָד רַכָּה עִם הָעוֹבְדִים.

nifal.note: Rare in modern Hebrew for driving

hifil.note: Shifts meaning to leadership rather than driving

litpos.rtm: Related to catching, grasping, or seizing

examples.hebrew: תָּפַסְתִּי דג גדול בים אתמול.
examples.translation: I caught a big fish in the sea yesterday.

examples.hebrew: תָּפַסְתָּ את הכדור בקלות.
examples.translation: You caught the ball easily.

examples.hebrew: אִמָּא, תָּפַסְתְּ אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ?
examples.translation: Mom, did you catch the key?

litpos.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ת-פ-ס is tied to catching or seizing, used both physically (e.g., catching a ball) and figuratively (e.g., understanding). It’s regular with no guttural sounds.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּפַס אֶת הַיּוֹם וְיָצָא לְטַיֵּל.

idioms.trl: to catch at this (take an opportunity)
idioms.usage: הִיא תָּפְסָה בַּזֹּאת וְהִתְחִילָה לַעֲבוֹד עַל הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

nifal.note: Common in passive contexts, e.g., being caught red-handed

examples.hebrew: מָשַׁכְתִּי אֶת הַדֶּלֶת בְּכֹחַ כְּדֵי לִפְתּוֹחַ אוֹתָהּ.
examples.translation: I pulled the door hard to open it.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה מָשַׁכְתָּ אֶת הַיְלָד מִן הַבּוֹר.
examples.translation: You pulled the child out of the well.

examples.hebrew: מָשַׁכְתְּ אֶת הַכִּסֵא קְרוֹב יוֹתֵר אֵלַי.
examples.translation: You pulled the chair closer to me.

limshoch.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root מ-ש-ך has no guttural sounds, making it straightforward to conjugate. It’s used for physical pulling or dragging, and occasionally figuratively (e.g., delaying).

idioms.usage: הוּא מָשַׁךְ בַּזֹּאת כְּדֵי לֹא לְהַחְלִיט מַהֵר.
הִיא מוֹשֶׁכֶת אֶת הַזְּמַן כְּדֵי לֹא לְדַבֵּר עִם הַבֹּס.

nifal.note: Often used for duration (e.g., 'it dragged on')

leharim.rtm: Related to raising, lifting, or height

examples.hebrew: הֲרִימוֹתִי את הַתִּינוֹק מִן הַמִּטָּה.
examples.translation: I lifted the baby from the crib.

examples.hebrew: הֲרִימוֹתָ את המשקל בקלות?
examples.translation: Did you lift the weight easily?

examples.hebrew: הֲרִימוֹת את הילדים בזרועותיה.
examples.translation: She lifted the children with her arms.

leharim.notes: This verb is in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often conveys causation or an active raising action. The root ר-ו-מ (r-u-m) relates to height or elevation, with the ו (vav) typically dropping in conjugation. It’s used both literally (lifting objects) and figuratively (raising spirits, voices).

idioms.usage: הַמְּאַמֵּן הֵרִים אֶת הַמּוֹרָל שֶׁל הַקְּבוּצָה.
הֵם הֵרִימוּ יָדַיִם לְתַמּוֹךְ בַּהַצָּעָה.

nifal.note: Common in passive or natural rising contexts

nikra_nifal.rtm: Related to reading, calling, or summoning

examples.hebrew: בַּיּוֹם שֶׁנִּקְרֵאתִי לְמִשְׁפָּט, הָיִיתִי מְאוֹד לַחוּץ.
examples.translation: On the day I was called to trial, I was very nervous.

examples.hebrew: אתמול נִקְרֵאתָ בשם שגוי במהלך הפגישה.
examples.translation: Yesterday, you were called by the wrong name during the meeting.

examples.hebrew: הספר נִקְרֵאתְ בקול רם על ידי הילדה.
examples.translation: The book was read aloud by the girl.

nikra_nifal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Nifal (נִפְעַל). The root ק.ר.א is associated with reading and calling, and in Nifal, it indicates a passive or reflexive action, such as being read or called.

idioms.trl: to be called by a good name
idioms.usage: הוּא נִקְרָא לְשֵׁם טוֹב בְּכָל הָעִיר.
הַתַּלְמִיד נִקְרָא לַמִּשְׁמָע בְּכִתָּה.

examples.hebrew: הייתי כל כך עסוק, שלא נִכְתַּבְתִּי ביומן שלי כבר שבוע.
examples.translation: I was so busy that I haven't been written in my diary for a week.

examples.hebrew: הידיעה נכתבת בידי העיתונאי הצעיר והמוכשר.
examples.translation: The article was written by the young and talented journalist.

examples.hebrew: הספר הזה נכתבת על ידי סופרת מפורסמת.
examples.translation: This book was written by a famous author.

nikhtav.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, used to indicate that the subject is being acted upon. For the root כ.ת.ב, it means 'to be written'. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future tense may be less commonly used, with masculine plural forms often substituted.

idioms.usage: הָאַהֲבָה שֶׁלָּהֶם נִכְתְּבָה בַּכּוֹכָבִים. (Their love was written in the stars.)

examples.hebrew: הִכְתַּבְתִּי לוֹ את ההוראות בדיוק כפי שביקשתי.
examples.translation: I dictated the instructions to him exactly as I requested.

examples.hebrew: הִכְתַּבְתָּ לי את המכתב כדי שאוכל לשלוח אותו בדואר.
examples.translation: You dictated the letter to me so I could send it by mail.

examples.hebrew: הִכְתַּבְתְּ אֶת הַמִּכְתָבִים בְּזָרִיזוּת.
examples.translation: You dictated the letters quickly.

hiktiv.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, meaning 'to cause something to be written'. For the root כ.ת.ב, it translates to 'to dictate'. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future and imperative may be less commonly used, with masculine plural forms often substituted.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת הִכְתִּיב אֶת הַקְּצָב לַפְּרוֹיֶקְט. (The team dictated the pace for the project.)

examples.hebrew: הֻכְתַּבְתִּי עַל־יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה לִכְתּוֹב אֶת הַשִּׁיעוּר.
examples.translation: I was dictated by the teacher to write the lesson.

examples.hebrew: הֻכְתַּבְתָּ את המכתב בדיוק כפי שביקשתי.
examples.translation: You dictated the letter exactly as I requested.

examples.hebrew: הֻכְתַּבְתְּ עַל־יְדֵי הַמּוֹרֶה בַּשִּׁעוּר.
examples.translation: You were dictated by the teacher during the lesson.

hukhtav.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, indicating that the subject is the recipient of the action of dictation. It is less commonly used in modern spoken Hebrew but appears in formal or written contexts. Feminine plural forms in the future tense may be replaced by masculine plural forms in casual speech.
similar_verbs: הֻשְׁמַע (to be played, to be made heard)

idioms.usage: הַחֲלָטוֹת הֻכְתְּבוּ מִלְּמַעְלָה עַל יְדֵי הַהַנְהָלָה. (The decisions were dictated from above by the management.)

hashmir.rtm: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁמַרְתִּי לוֹ את המפתחות כדי שיוכל לחזור הביתה מאוחר.
examples.translation: I entrusted him with the keys so he could return home late.

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁמַרְתָּ אֶת הַסּוֹד שֶׁלִי בְּמִשְׁמֶרֶת?
examples.translation: Did you keep my secret safe?

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁמַרְתְּ לִי אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ וְלֹא הֵאָמַנְתִּי בְּךָ.
examples.translation: You entrusted me with the key and I did not trust you.

hashmir.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, meaning 'to cause to guard' or 'to entrust'. For שׁ.מ.ר, it often implies assigning someone to guard or entrusting something to their care. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future and imperative may be less common, with masculine plural forms sometimes used instead.

idioms.usage: הִשְׁמַרְנוּ אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט בְּיָדֵי נֶאֱמָן. (We entrusted the project into faithful hands.)

halmid.rtm: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.hebrew: הִלְמַדְתִּי לְרוּץ בַּבּוֹקֶר כדי לְשַׁמֵּר אֶת הַכּוֹשֶׂר.
examples.translation: I trained to run in the morning to maintain my fitness.

examples.hebrew: הִלְמַדְתָּ לִרְכּוֹב עַל אוֹפָנָיִים כְּשֶׁהָיִיתָ יֶלֶד?
examples.translation: Did you learn to ride a bicycle when you were a child?

examples.hebrew: הִלְמַדְתְּ בַּיִת אוֹתִי לִהְיוֹת חֲזָקָה יוֹתֵר.
examples.translation: You trained me at home to be stronger.

halmid.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to learn' to 'to cause to learn' or 'to train'. For ל.מ.ד, it often implies actively training or enabling someone to acquire a skill or knowledge. While less common than Pi'el ('to teach'), it’s used in contexts emphasizing structured training or causation.

idioms.trl: to train to know (to instill knowledge)
idioms.usage: הִלְמַדְתִּי אוֹתוֹ לְדַעַת אֵיךְ לִפְתֹּר בְּעָיוֹת. (I trained him to know how to solve problems.)

hakria.rtm: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.hebrew: הִקְרֵאתִי אֶת כָּל הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה לְסֵעוּדָה בְּשַׁבָּת.
examples.translation: I invited the whole family for a meal on Saturday.

examples.hebrew: הִקְרֵאתָ אוֹתִי לְחַגִיגָה בַּבַּיִת שֶׁלְּךָ?
examples.translation: Did you invite me to a party at your house?

examples.hebrew: הִקְרֵאתְ אוֹתוֹ לְבַּיִת שֶׁלָּךְ לְאָרוּחָה.
examples.translation: You invited him to your house for dinner.

hakria.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to read' or 'to call' into 'to cause to read' or 'to invite'. In modern Hebrew, 'to invite' is the dominant usage, while 'to cause to read' appears in educational contexts. It’s moderately common, particularly for social or formal invitations.

idioms.trl: invited for the sake of appearance (token invitation)
idioms.usage: הִקְרִיאוּ אוֹתוֹ לְשֵׁם תּוֹפָעָה בִּלְבַד. (They invited him just for show.)

nishma.rtm: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.hebrew: הייתי בהופעה והנגן נִשְׁמַעְתִּי מעולה.
examples.translation: I was at the concert and the musician sounded excellent.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בלילה נִשְׁמַעְתָּ מדבר בשינה.
examples.translation: Last night you were heard talking in your sleep.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בלילה נִשְׁמַעַתְּ בקול רם מדי.
examples.translation: Last night you were heard too loudly.

nishma.notes: Nif'al serves as the passive of Pa'al ('to hear'), meaning 'to be heard'. It’s commonly used in modern Hebrew to describe sounds or voices being audible, and it’s frequent in both spoken and written contexts.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּר שֶׁלּוֹ נִשְׁמַע כְּמוֹ אֱמֶת. (His story sounds like the truth.)

hushma.rtm: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.hebrew: הֻשְׁמַעְתִּי על התכנית החדשה ברדיו.
examples.translation: I was informed about the new program on the radio.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שרות הטלפון, הֻשְׁמַעְתָּ על השינוי בתוכניות.
examples.translation: After the phone call, you were informed about the change in plans.

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ הֻשְׁמַעַתְּ מֵאִתּוֹ שֶׁהוּא לֹא יָכוֹל לָבוֹא הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: You were informed by him that he cannot come today.

hushma.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to hear' or 'to inform' into 'to be made to hear' or 'to be informed'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, such as broadcasts or official notifications.

idioms.usage: הַהַחְלָטָה הֻשְׁמְעָה לְרַבִּים בִּזְמַן אֲמִתִּי. (The decision was informed to the masses in real time.)

davar.rtm: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.hebrew: דָּבַרְתִּי עִם הַמּוֹרֶה שֶׁלִּי עַל הַשִּׁיעוּרִים.
examples.translation: I spoke with my teacher about the lessons.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שהדברת עם המנהל, האם יש לך חדשות?
examples.translation: After you spoke with the manager, do you have any news?

examples.hebrew: כשדָּבַרְתְּ איתו, האם הבנת את כל מה שהוא אמר?
examples.translation: When you spoke with him, did you understand everything he said?

davar.notes: Pa'al for ד.ב.ר means 'to speak' in a general sense, often used with direct objects or prepositions (e.g., 'with someone'). While Pi'el ( diber - 'to speak') is more common in modern Hebrew for formal or prolonged speech, Pa'al remains a simpler, foundational form, especially in biblical Hebrew or poetic contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא דָּבַר מִלֵּב וְרִגֵּשׁ אֶת כֻּלָּם. (He spoke from the heart and moved everyone.)

naasah.rtm: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.hebrew: נַעֲשֵׂיתִי מָלֵא בִּרְגָשׁוֹת אַחֲרֵי הַמּוֹפָע.
examples.translation: I was filled with emotions after the show.

examples.hebrew: כשהגעת לבית הספר, נַעֲשֵׂיתָ מורה מצוין.
examples.translation: When you arrived at the school, you became an excellent teacher.

examples.hebrew: היא נַעֲשֵׂיתְ כבר את כל המטלות שלה לפני שיצאה לעבודה.
examples.translation: She had already done all her chores before she left for work.

naasah.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to do' or 'to make' into 'to be done' or 'to be made'. It’s very common in modern Hebrew, used for both literal actions (e.g., cooking) and abstract completions (e.g., tasks), making it a versatile and frequent form.

idioms.usage: הַכֹּל נַעֲשָׂה בְּרֶגַע כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעַ הַזְּמַן. (Everything was done in a moment when the time came.)

mng: to be caused to be done

huda.rtm: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing
mng: to be caused to be known

examples.hebrew: הוּדַעְתִּי עַל הַשִׁינּוּיִים בַּמַּעֲרָכֶת.
examples.translation: I was informed about the changes in the system.

examples.hebrew: הוּדַעְתָּ לִי כְּבָר שֶׁהַמִּסְעָדָה סְגוּרָה הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: You already informed me that the restaurant is closed today.

examples.hebrew: הוּדַעַתְּ לִי אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת בְּבוֹקֶר.
examples.translation: You informed me of the news in the morning.

huda.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to know' or 'to inform' into 'to be caused to be known' or 'to be informed'. It’s moderately used in modern Hebrew, often in formal or written contexts, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be known') and Pu'al ('to be informed') but tied to Hif'il’s causative action.
similar_verbs: הֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.usage: הַסּוֹד הוּדַע בְּרַבִּים אַחֲרֵי הַדְּלִיפָה. (The secret was informed to many after the leak.)

mng: to be caused to be known

nechshav.rtm: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: נֶחְשַׁבְתִּי לְחָכָם בְּכִתָּה.
examples.translation: I was considered wise in class.

examples.hebrew: נֶחְשַׁבְתָּ לְאָדָם הַגּוֹן עַד שֶׁהִתְגַּלָה הָאֱמֶת.
examples.translation: You were thought to be an honest person until the truth came out.

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ נֶחְשַׁבְתְּ לְמִתְנַדֶּבֶת הַכִּי טוֹבָה בַּקְּהִלָּה.
examples.translation: You were considered the best volunteer in the community.

nechshav.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to think' into 'to be thought' or 'to be considered'. It’s widely used in modern Hebrew to express being regarded or evaluated, making it a common and versatile form.

idioms.usage: הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט נֶחְשַׁב בְּרֹאשׁ בְּתוֹכְנִית הַשָּׁנָה. (The project was thought at the forefront of the year’s plan.)

examples.hebrew: הִשַּׁרְתִּי את הציפורים בבוקר.
examples.translation: I caused the birds to sing in the morning.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה הִשַּׁרְתָּ אֶת הַצִּפּוֹרִים בַּבּוֹקֶר.
examples.translation: You made the birds sing in the morning.

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ הִשַּׁרְתְּ אֶת הַצִּפּוֹרִים בַּבּוֹקֶר.
examples.translation: You caused the birds to sing in the morning.

hashir.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to sing' (שר) into 'to cause to sing'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used in educational or performative contexts where someone prompts others to sing.
related_words: מַשִּׁיר (causing to sing, rare as adjective)

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשִּׁיר אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּקוֹל רָם בַּחֲגִיגוֹת. (He caused the audience to sing loudly at the celebrations.)

mng: to be caused to be sung
to be caused to be sung
