inf.trl: to be caused to be sung

examples.hebrew: בבוקר הֻשַּׁרְתִּי לראשונה ברדיו.
examples.translation: In the morning, I was sung for the first time on the radio.

examples.hebrew: בזכות הקהל המעולה, הֻשַּׁרְתָּ בהצלחה רבה.
examples.translation: Thanks to the excellent audience, you were successfully caused to be sung.

examples.hebrew: בבית הספר הֻשַּׁרְתְּ שירים חדשים לתלמידים.
examples.translation: At school, new songs were sung to the students.

hushar.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to sing' into 'to be caused to be sung'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be sung') but with a stronger causative nuance from Hif'il.
related_words: מֻשָּׁר (caused to be sung, rare as adjective)
similar_verbs: לְהֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.trl: caused to be sung with joy
idioms.usage: הַשִּׁירִים הֻשְּׁרוּ בְּשִׂמְחָה בְּיוֹם הַחֲגִיגָה. (The songs were caused to be sung with joy on the celebration day.)

mng: to be caused to be sung

naratz.rtm: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.hebrew: אחרי שהִתְאַמַּנְתִּי בחדר הכושר, נִרְצֵיתִי עד תום.
examples.translation: After I worked out at the gym, I was completely exhausted.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שנִרְצֵיתָ בשבעה מרתונים, אתה באמת יכול להתגאות בכושר שלך.
examples.translation: After you were run in seven marathons, you can truly be proud of your fitness.

examples.hebrew: לאחר שנִרְצֵיתְ, הרגשתי שהכביש נעשה בטוח יותר.
examples.translation: After you were run over, I felt that the road became safer.

naratz.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to run' into 'to be run' or 'to be raced'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for races or courses being completed, contrasting with Pa'al’s active sense of running.

idioms.usage: הַמֵּרוֹץ נָרַץ בְּרֹאשׁ עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים הַמְּהִירִים. (The race was run at the head by the fastest students.)

mng: to be caused to be run

haritz.rtm: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.hebrew: הֲרַצְתִּי את המכונה כדי לבדוק אם היא עובדת כמו שצריך.
examples.translation: I ran the machine to check if it works properly.

examples.hebrew: הֲרַצָּתָּ את המכונה כדי לבדוק אם היא עובדת?
examples.translation: Did you run the machine to check if it works?

examples.hebrew: הֲרַצְתְּ את המכונה כדי לבדוק אם היא עובדת?
examples.translation: Did you run the machine to check if it's working?

haritz.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to run' into 'to cause to run' or 'to accelerate'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, used both literally (e.g., making someone run) and figuratively (e.g., speeding up processes), contrasting with Pa'al’s direct action.

idioms.trl: caused the winds to run (stirred things up)
idioms.usage: הוּא הֵרִיץ אֶת הָרוּחוֹת בְּקֶרֶב הַצָּוֶת לְהַתְחִיל אֶת הַמֵּרוֹץ. (He stirred things up among the team to start the race.)

mng: to be caused to be run

examples.hebrew: הִתְאַהַבְתִּי בוֹ ברגע שראיתי אותו.
examples.translation: I fell in love with him the moment I saw him.

examples.hebrew: הִתְאַהַבְתָּ בַּחֲבֵרָה שֶׁל אָחִיךָ.
examples.translation: You fell in love with your brother's friend.

examples.hebrew: הִתְאַהַבְתְּ בוֹ בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁפְּגַשְׁתְּ אוֹתוֹ.
examples.translation: You fell in love with him the first time you met him.

hitahev.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For א.ה.ב, it primarily means 'to fall in love' (reflexive affection toward someone or something) and less commonly 'to make oneself loved'. It’s very common in modern Hebrew, especially in romantic contexts, contrasting with Pa'al’s general 'to love'.

idioms.trl: fell in love head and heart
idioms.usage: הִתְאַהֲבָה בּוֹ מֵרֹאשׁ וּמֵלֵב בַּפְּגִישָׁה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה. (She fell in love with him head and heart at the first meeting.)

mng: to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: נִפְגַּשְׁתִּי עם חבר ותיק בבית קפה אתמול.
examples.translation: I met an old friend at a cafe yesterday.

examples.hebrew: אתמול נִפְגַּשְׁתָּ עם חבריך בפארק.
examples.translation: Yesterday you met with your friends in the park.

examples.hebrew: כשהגעתי לבית הקפה, נִפְגַּשְׁתְּ כבר עם חברותייך?
examples.translation: When I arrived at the café, had you already met with your friends?

hifagesh.notes: Nif'al is often used for passive or reflexive actions. In this case, לְהִפָּגֵשׁ means 'to meet each other' or 'to be met.' It’s commonly used in social contexts to describe mutual meetings or gatherings.

idioms.usage: הֵם הִפָּגְשׁוּ בְּאֶמְצַע הַדֶּרֶךְ לְפַתֵּר אֶת הַבְּעָיָה. (Hem nifgeshu be'emtzah ha-derekh lefater et ha-be'ayah.) - They met halfway to solve the problem.

examples.hebrew: בסוף נִבְחַרְתִּי להיות הנציג של הכיתה.
examples.translation: In the end, I was chosen to be the class representative.

examples.hebrew: נִבְחַרְתָּ לְהִיוֹת הַנָּשִׂיא הַחָדָשׁ שֶׁל הַמְדִינָה.
examples.translation: You were chosen to be the new president of the country.

examples.hebrew: נִבְחַרְתְּ לְהִתְמַנּוֹת לְתַפְקִיד חָשׁוּב בַּמּוֹסָד.
examples.translation: You were chosen to be appointed to an important position in the institution.

hivacher.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to choose' into 'to be chosen.' It’s commonly used in contexts involving selection or election, such as in competitions, elections, or appointments.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִבְחַר בְּטוֹב לַתַּפְקִיד. (Hu nivchar betov la'tafkid.) - He was chosen for good for the role.

mng: to be caused to be chosen (rare)

examples.hebrew: הִצְחַקְתִּי אֶת כָּל הַחֲבֵרִים בַּמְּסִיבָה.
examples.translation: I made all my friends laugh at the party.

examples.hebrew: אתמול הִצְחַקְתָּ אותי עם הבדיחה שלך.
examples.translation: Yesterday you made me laugh with your joke.

examples.hebrew: הִצְחַקְתְּ אוֹתִי עִם הַבְּדִיחָה הַזּוֹ.
examples.translation: You made me laugh with that joke.

lehatzchik.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of the verb, turning 'to laugh' into 'to make laugh' or 'to cause laughter.' It’s commonly used in contexts where someone or something induces laughter, such as through humor, jokes, or amusing situations.

idioms.usage: הַקוֹמִיקַאי הִצְחִיק אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּמִשְׁךְ שָׁעָה. (Ha'komikai hitzchik et ha'kahal bemeshech sha'ah.) - The comedian made the audience laugh for an hour.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בבוקר נראיתי ממש טוב במראה.
examples.translation: Yesterday morning I looked really good in the mirror.

examples.hebrew: אתמול נִרְאֵיתָ ממש עייף.
examples.translation: Yesterday you looked really tired.

examples.hebrew: אתמול נִרְאֵית ממש יפה בשמלה החדשה שלך.
examples.translation: Yesterday you looked really beautiful in your new dress.

leheraot.notes: Nif'al is often used for passive or stative actions. In this case, it means 'to be seen' or 'to appear,' indicating visibility or presence. It’s commonly used in contexts where something becomes visible or is perceived.

idioms.trl: to be seen in the eyes of the world
idioms.usage: הוּא רוֹצֶה לְהֵרָאוֹת בְּעֵינֵי הָעוֹלָם כְּאִישׁ מַצְלִיחַ. (Hu rotzeh lehera'ot be'einei ha'olam ke'ish matzliach.) - He wants to be seen in the eyes of the world as a successful man.

examples.hebrew: הִפְעַלְתִּי את המכשיר החדש שלי הבוקר.
examples.translation: I activated my new device this morning.

examples.hebrew: הִפְעַלְתָּ את המכשיר והוא התחיל לעבוד מייד.
examples.translation: You activated the device and it started working immediately.

examples.hebrew: הִפְעַלְתְּ את המכונה בבוקר?
examples.translation: Did you activate the machine in the morning?

lehaf'il.notes: Hif'il often serves as the causative form of Pa'al, turning 'to act' from Pa'al (לִפְעֹל) into 'to cause to act' or 'to activate' in Hif'il (לְהַפְעִיל). It’s commonly used in technological or operational contexts, such as activating devices or operating systems.

idioms.usage: הַמּוֹרֶה הִפְעִיל אֶת הַמַּחְשָׁבָה שֶׁל הַתַּלְמִידִים. (The teacher activated the students' minds.)

examples.hebrew: בַּתְּחִלַת הַפַּגִישָׁה נֶאֱמַרְתִּי כִּי אֲנִי הַמַּנְחֶה הַחָדָשׁ.
examples.translation: At the beginning of the meeting, I was said to be the new host.

examples.hebrew: אתמול נֶאֱמַרְתָּ לי שהכל בסדר, אבל היום אני רואה שהמצב שונה.
examples.translation: Yesterday you told me everything was fine, but today I see the situation is different.

examples.hebrew: בַּחֲצָאי הַלַּיְלָה נֶאֱמַרְתְּ שֶׁתֵּצְאִי לִמְשִׁמְשֵׁי הַיָּרֵחַ.
examples.translation: In the middle of the night, you were said to go out to enjoy the moonlight.

le'amer.notes: Nif'al is often the passive form of Pa'al. For אמר, it shifts from 'to say' in Pa'al (לֵאמֹר) to 'to be said' in Nif'al (לֵאָמֵר). It is commonly used in formal or narrative contexts to indicate something that was or will be said.

idioms.usage: הַתָּכְנִית נֶאֱמַר וְנַעֲשָׂה בְּדִיּוּק. (The plan was said and done precisely.)

mng: to be caused to be said (rare)

examples.hebrew: אמש הֵיְשַׁנְתִּי את הילדים מוקדם יותר בגלל הטיול המוקדם של הבוקר.
examples.translation: Last night I put the children to sleep earlier because of the early morning trip.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה הֵיְשַׁנְתָּ אֶת הַיֶּלֶד אֶתְמוֹל בָּעֶרֶב?
examples.translation: Did you put the child to sleep last night?

examples.hebrew: אַתְּ הֵיְשַׁנְתְּ אֶת הַיֶּלֶד אֶתְמוֹל בַּלַּיְלָה?
examples.translation: Did you put the child to sleep last night?

lehayshen.notes: Hif'il often serves as the causative form of Pa'al. For ישנ, it shifts from 'to sleep' in Pa'al (לִישׁוֹן) to 'to put to sleep' in Hif'il (לְהַיְשִׁין). It is commonly used in caregiving or medical contexts to indicate causing someone to sleep.

idioms.trl: to put the mind to sleep
idioms.usage: הַסִּרְטוֹן הֵיְשִׁין אֶת הַדַּעַת שֶׁלִּי. (The video put my mind to sleep.)

examples.hebrew: הֻזְמַנְתִּי לחתונה של חברי הטוב בשבוע הבא.
examples.translation: I was invited to my best friend's wedding next week.

examples.hebrew: הֻזְמַנְתָּ לחתונה של חברך הטוב.
examples.translation: You were invited to your best friend's wedding.

examples.hebrew: הֻזְמַנְתְּ לחתונה של חברה הכי טובה שלך.
examples.translation: You were invited to your best friend's wedding.

lehuzman.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, used for actions where someone or something is invited. It is less common than other binyanim but appears in formal or written contexts.

examples.hebrew: כשעבדתי במחסן, נִשְׁמַשְׁתִּי בכלים ישנים שנמצאו שם.
examples.translation: When I worked in the warehouse, I was used with old tools that were found there.

examples.hebrew: בחופשה האחרונה שלנו, נִשְׁמַשְׁתָּ בכלי הגינון כדי לטפח את הגן.
examples.translation: On our last vacation, you used the gardening tools to tend to the garden.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שהנשמשת בכל הכלים, הם נראים כמו חדשים.
examples.translation: After you used all the tools, they look brand new.

lehishamesh.notes: The Nif'al form of the root שׁ-מ-שׁ indicates the passive form of using something. It is often used in contexts where an object or tool is being utilized, such as in technical or everyday settings.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִשְׁמַשׁ בְּסַכִּין לַחֲתֹךְ. (Hu nishmash be’sakin lachatoch.) - He used a knife to cut.

mng: to be caused to be used (rare)

examples.hebrew: הֻסְבַּרְתִּי את התופעה המדעית הזו לתלמידים.
examples.translation: I explained this scientific phenomenon to the students.

examples.hebrew: הֻסְבַּרְתָּ את המושג בצורה ברורה מאוד.
examples.translation: You explained the concept very clearly.

examples.hebrew: הֻסְבַּרְתְּ לי את המצב בצורה ברורה מאוד.
examples.translation: You explained the situation to me very clearly.

lehusbar.notes: Huf’al is the passive form of Hif’il, used here to indicate that something is being explained. It is less common and typically found in formal or technical contexts.

idioms.usage: הַנּוֹשֵׂא הֻסְבַּר בְּפֵרוּשׁ. (Ha’nose husbar be’ferush.) - The topic was explained explicitly.

examples.hebrew: נֶאֱמַנְתִּי לְחֲבֵרִי בְּזִמָּנִים קָשִׁים.
examples.translation: I was faithful to my friend in difficult times.

examples.hebrew: כשאמרת שתהיה שם בשבילי, נֶאֱמַנְתָּ למילה שלך.
examples.translation: When you said you would be there for me, you were faithful to your word.

examples.hebrew: בכל הזמן הזה, נֶאֱמַנְתְּ לי ואף פעם לא בגדת בי.
examples.translation: All this time, you have been faithful to me and never betrayed me.

leheamen.notes: Passive/reflexive form of the root ["א", "מ", "נ"], meaning 'to be faithful' or 'to be believed.' Often used in contexts of trust or loyalty, e.g., 'He was faithful to his word.'

idioms.usage: הוּא נֶאֱמַן לְעַצְמוֹ בְּכָל הַחְלָטוֹת. (Hu ne'eman le'atzmo be'chol ha'hachlatot.) - He is faithful to himself in all decisions.

examples.hebrew: הִרְאֵיתִי לוֹ אֶת הַתְּמוּנָה הַיָּפָה שֶׁל הַשֶׁמֶשׁ הַשּׁוֹקַעַת.
examples.translation: I showed him the beautiful picture of the setting sun.

examples.hebrew: הִרְאֵיתָ לִי אֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ הַחֲדָשָׁה בַּיַעֲרוֹת.
examples.translation: You showed me the new path in the forest.

examples.hebrew: הִרְאֵיתְ לִי אֵיךְ לַעֲשׂוֹת אֶת הַמַּתְכוֹן הַחָדָשׁ.
examples.translation: You showed me how to make the new recipe.

leharot.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ר-א-ה shifts the meaning from 'to see' (Pa'al) to 'to cause to see' or 'to show.' It is a common verb in both formal and informal contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִרְאָה לִי אֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ לַתַּחֲנָה. (Hu hir'a li et ha'derech la'tachana.) - He showed me the way to the station.

lehavin.rtm: Related to understanding, discerning, or perceiving

examples.hebrew: בִּינְתִּי שֶׁהַמַּצָב קָשֶׁה מִכְפִּי שֶׁחָשַׁבְתִּי.
examples.translation: I discerned that the situation is harder than I thought.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שדיברנו, בִּינְתָּ את המצב וידעת מה לעשות.
examples.translation: After we talked, you discerned the situation and knew what to do.

examples.hebrew: אחרי שדיברנו, בִּינְתְּ את המצב וקיבלת החלטה.
examples.translation: After we talked, you discerned the situation and made a decision.

lehavin.notes: Regular verb in Pa'al binyan. Commonly used for both 'to discern' and 'to understand' depending on context.

idioms.trl: to discern between good and evil

examples.hebrew: הִפְגַּשְׁתִּי בֵּין שְׁנֵי הַחֲבֵרִים שֶׁלִּי בְּבִטְחָה.
examples.translation: I arranged a meeting between my two friends safely.

examples.hebrew: הִפְגַּשְׁתָּ אוֹתִי עִם חָבֵר שֶׁלְּךָ מֵהָעֲבוֹדָה.
examples.translation: You arranged a meeting for me with your friend from work.

examples.hebrew: הִפְגַּשְׁתְּ אוֹתוֹ עִם חֲבֵרָהּ מֵהָעֲבוֹדָה.
examples.translation: You arranged for him to meet her friend from work.

lehafgish.notes: Hif'il form shifts the Pa'al meaning 'to meet' to a causative 'to arrange a meeting'.

examples.hebrew: במהלך הקריירה שלי, שִׁמַּשְׁתִּי כמנהל פרויקטים בחברה גדולה.
examples.translation: During my career, I served as a project manager in a large company.

examples.hebrew: שִׁמַּשְׁתָּ כְּמַתְרֶגֵם בַּצָּבָא.
examples.translation: You served as a translator in the army.

examples.hebrew: הוא שִׁמֵּשׁ כמנהל בית הספר במשך עשר שנים.
examples.translation: He served as the school principal for ten years.

leshamesh.notes: Regular Pa'al verb. Can mean 'to serve' (e.g., a person) or 'to use' (e.g., an object).

examples.hebrew: הִכְנַסְתִּי את כל החלקים של המדף ועכשיו הוא מוכן לשימוש.
examples.translation: I assembled all the parts of the shelf and now it's ready for use.

examples.hebrew: הִכְנִיס אֶת כָּל הַחֲלָקִים לְתוֹך הַמִּכְשׁוֹל.
examples.translation: He assembled all the parts into the device.

examples.hebrew: אני מכניס את כל החלקים כדי לבנות את המדף.
examples.translation: I am assembling all the parts to build the shelf.

lehachnis.notes: Hif'il form shifts Pa'al 'to enter' to causative 'to bring in' or 'to assemble'.

leamen.rtm: Related to trust, faith, or belief

examples.hebrew: אָמַנְתִּי בוֹ לְחָלוֹטִין, וְלֹא הִתְאַכְזַבְתִּי.
examples.translation: I trusted him completely, and I was not disappointed.

examples.hebrew: אָמַנְתָּ בּוֹ מִיָּד כְּשֶׁפָּגַשְׁתָּ אוֹתוֹ.
examples.translation: You trusted him immediately when you met him.

examples.hebrew: אָמַנְתְּ בוֹ מִיָּד כְּשֶׁרָאִיתִי אוֹתוֹ.
examples.translation: You trusted him immediately when I saw him.

leamen.notes: This verb is less common in Modern Hebrew and is often replaced by 'לִבְטוֹחַ' (to trust). It may appear in more formal or religious contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא אָמַן בְּעַצְמוֹ לְהַצְלִיחַ. (Hu aman be'atzmo lehatsliach.) - He trusted himself to succeed.

examples.hebrew: סִדַּרְתִּי את כל המסמכים בתיקייה.
examples.translation: I arranged all the documents in the folder.

examples.hebrew: אתמול סִדַּרְתָּ את החדר שלך יפה מאוד.
examples.translation: Yesterday you arranged your room very nicely.

examples.hebrew: אתמול סִדַּרְתְּ את הספרים בחדר הילדים.
examples.translation: Yesterday you arranged the books in the children's room.

lesader.notes: The Pi'el form of the root ס-ד-ר is commonly used in Modern Hebrew for arranging or organizing physical objects or abstract concepts.

idioms.usage: הוּא סִדֵּר אֶת הַדְּבָרִים בְּסֵדֶר מוֹפְתִי. (Hu sider et ha'dvarim be'seder mofeti.) - He arranged things in perfect order.

likdom.rtm: Related to preceding or being early

examples.hebrew: קָדַמְתִּי אוֹתוֹ בַּמִּסְעוּדָה הַזּוֹ.
examples.translation: I preceded him at this meal.

examples.hebrew: קָדַמְתָּ אוֹתִי בַּתּוֹר לַחֲנוּת הַיְרָקוֹת.
examples.translation: You preceded me in line at the grocery store.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה קָדַמְתְּ אוֹתִי בַּמִּשְׁמָר.
examples.translation: You preceded me in the shift.

likdom.notes: The Pa'al form of the root ק-ד-מ is used in Modern Hebrew to indicate preceding in time or order. It is moderately common.

idioms.usage: הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ קָדְמָה לַיָּרֵחַ בְּזְמַן. (Ha'shemesh kadma la'yareach be'zman.) - The sun preceded the moon in time.

examples.hebrew: ברגע שהתחלתי לדבר, פסקתי מיד לשתות את הקפה.
examples.translation: The moment I started talking, I immediately ceased drinking my coffee.

examples.hebrew: כשהפסקת לדבר, הבנתי שמשהו לא בסדר.
examples.translation: When you stopped talking, I realized something was wrong.

examples.hebrew: כשהגיעה לבית הספר, פָּסַקְתְּ לדבר והתחלת ללמוד.
examples.translation: When she arrived at school, she ceased talking and started studying.

pasek.notes: The verb לפסוק in Pa'al is used to indicate the cessation of an action or state, such as stopping an activity or an event coming to an end. It is commonly used in both formal and informal contexts.
related_words: פּוֹסֵק (posek) - one who ceases or a decider in Jewish law

idioms.usage: הוּא פָּסַק מִלְּדַבֵּר בְּאֶמְצַע הַדִּבּוּר. (Hu pasak mil'daber be'emtzah ha'dibur.) - He stopped speaking in the middle of the speech.

shaar.rtm: Related to remaining or being left

examples.hebrew: שָׁאַרְתִּי בבית כדי לסיים את העבודה.
examples.translation: I stayed at home to finish the work.

examples.hebrew: שָׁאַרְתָּ בבית כדי לסיים את העבודה.
examples.translation: You stayed at home to finish the work.

examples.hebrew: אתמול בלילה, כשהיית בחוץ, שָׁאַרְתְּ בבית לבד.
examples.translation: Last night, when you were out, you remained at home alone.

shaar.notes: The verb לִשְׁאֹר in Pa'al is used to indicate remaining or being left behind. It is commonly used in contexts where something or someone stays in a particular state or place. Note that the root שׁ-א-ר has a guttural letter (א), which affects conjugation patterns, particularly in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׁאַר בְּלִי כֶּסֶף. (Hu sha'ar bli kesef.) - He remained without money.

examples.hebrew: חָפַשְׂתִּי בכל מקום אפשרי למצוא את המפתחות.
examples.translation: I searched everywhere to find the keys.

examples.hebrew: חָפַשְׂתָּ בכל מקום אפשרי למצוא את המפתחות.
examples.translation: You searched in every possible place to find the keys.

examples.hebrew: חָפַשְׂתְּ בכל מקום אפשרי למצוא את המפתח.
examples.translation: You searched every possible place to find the key.

chafas.notes: The verb לַחְפֹּשׂ in Pa'al is used to indicate seeking or searching for something. It is commonly used in both literal and figurative contexts, such as looking for physical objects or seeking knowledge or truth. Note that the root ח-פ-ש has a guttural letter (ח), which affects pronunciation and conjugation patterns, particularly in the imperative and future tenses.
similar_verbs: לְחַפֵּשׂ (lechapes) - to search (Pi'el form of the same root)

idioms.usage: הוּא חָפַשׂ אֶת הָאֱמֶת בְּכָל מָקוֹם. (Hu chafas et ha'emet be'chol makom.) - He sought the truth everywhere.

mng: to be caused to be sought (rare)

examples.hebrew: קָשַׁרְתִּי את המתנה בסרט אדום.
examples.translation: I tied the gift with a red ribbon.

examples.hebrew: קָשַׁרְתָּ את החבל חזק מדי, עכשיו לא מצליחים לפתוח אותו.
examples.translation: You tied the rope too tightly, now we can't untie it.

examples.hebrew: אתמול קָשַׁרְתְּ את השרוך של הנעליים שלך בצורה מושלמת.
examples.translation: Yesterday you tied your shoelaces perfectly.

kashar.notes: The verb לִקְשֹׁר in Pa'al is used to indicate tying or binding something physically, such as ropes or laces. It can also be used metaphorically, as in tying relationships or connections. The root ק-ש-ר is regular and follows standard Pa'al conjugation patterns.

idioms.usage: הוּא קָשַׁר קֶשֶׁר חָזָק. (Hu kashar kesher chazak.) - He tied a strong knot.

mng: to be caused to be tied (rare)

examples.hebrew: כשסיפרתי לו את האמת, גָּלִיתִי לו את כל הסודות שלי.
examples.translation: When I told him the truth, I revealed all my secrets to him.

examples.hebrew: אַתָּה גָּלִיתָ לִי אֶת הַסּוֹד הַכִּי גָּדוֹל שֶׁלְּךָ.
examples.translation: You revealed to me your biggest secret.

examples.hebrew: גָּלִית לִי אֶת הַסּוֹד בְּסוֹף.
examples.translation: You finally revealed the secret to me.

liglot.notes: גלה primarily means 'to reveal' or 'to uncover' in modern Hebrew. It can also historically mean 'to go into exile,' though this usage is rare today.

idioms.usage: הוּא גָּלָה אֶת הַקַּלְפִּים שֶׁלּוֹ. (He revealed his cards.)

examples.hebrew: הִבְחַרְתִּי בוֹ לִהְיוֹת מנהיג הקבוצה.
examples.translation: I chose him to be the leader of the group.

examples.hebrew: אחרי ששוחחנו, הִבְחַרְתָּ בדרך שתוביל אותך להצלחה.
examples.translation: After we talked, you chose the path that will lead you to success.

examples.hebrew: בָּאֲמֶת הִבְחַרְתְּ אוֹתוֹ לַתְפְקִיד הַזֶּה?
examples.translation: Did you really choose him for this position?

lehavchir.notes: The Hif'il form of בחר is rare and theoretical, implying a causative action ('to cause to choose'). The common form for 'to select' or 'to choose' is בחר in Pa'al (לִבְחֹר).

examples.hebrew: הִזְכַּרְתִּי לוֹ לקנות חלב בדרך הביתה.
examples.translation: I reminded him to buy milk on the way home.

examples.hebrew: כשאתה הִזְכַּרְתָּ אותי בזה, נזכרתי בכל המקרים הטובים.
examples.translation: When you reminded me of it, I remembered all the good times.

examples.hebrew: הִזְכַּרְתְּ לי את היום ההוא בחוף הים.
examples.translation: You reminded me of that day at the beach.

lehazkir.notes: In Hif'il, זכר means 'to remind,' a common causative form of the Pa'al 'to remember' (לִזְכֹּר). It is widely used in everyday Hebrew.

idioms.trl: to remind someone of what they forgot
idioms.usage: הִזְכַּרְתִּי לוֹ אֶת מָה שֶׁשָּׁכַח. (I reminded him of what he forgot.)

examples.hebrew: הוֹשַׁבְתִּי אֶת הַיְלָדִים לִשְׁמֹעַ סִפּוּר.
examples.translation: I seated the children to listen to a story.

examples.hebrew: הוֹשַׁבְתָּ אֶת הַיְלָדִים בַּמִּטְבָּח.
examples.translation: You seated the children in the kitchen.

examples.hebrew: אִמָּא הוֹשַׁבְתְּ אוֹתִי לִיד הַחַלּוֹן כְּדֵי לִרְאוֹת אֶת הַנּוֹף.
examples.translation: Mom, you seated me by the window to see the view.

lehoshev_hifil.notes: Hif'il is the causative form. For ישב, it shifts from 'to sit' in Pa'al to 'to cause to sit' or 'to seat'. Often used for arranging seating or placing people.

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱמַדְתִּי את הציור בחדר הילדים.
examples.translation: I positioned the painting in the children's room.

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱמַדְתָּ את הכסא ליד השולחן.
examples.translation: You positioned the chair next to the table.

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱמַדְתְּ את הילדים בשורה ישרה.
examples.translation: You positioned the children in a straight line.

leha'amid.notes: Hif'il is the causative form. For עמד, it shifts from 'to stand' in Pa'al to 'to cause to stand' or 'to position'. Used for placing objects or people in a standing position.

examples.hebrew: פִּתַּחְתִּי מערכת חדשה לניהול משימות בעבודה.
examples.translation: I developed a new system for managing tasks at work.

examples.hebrew: פִּתַּחְתָּ תוכנה חדשנית שמשנה את חוקי המשחק.
examples.translation: You developed an innovative software that changes the rules of the game.

examples.hebrew: את פִּתַּחְתְּ תוכנה חדשה שמשנה את חיינו.
examples.translation: You developed a new software that changes our lives.

lepateach.notes: Pi'el often indicates an intensive or causative action. For פתח, it shifts from 'to open' in Pa'al to 'to develop' or 'to open up' in a more intensive sense. Commonly used in contexts like software or project development.

mng: to be caused to be opened (rare)

leha'alot.rtm: Related to going up or ascending

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱלֵיתִי את הדגל למעלה על ההר.
examples.translation: I raised the flag up on the mountain.

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱלֵיתָ את הנושא בפגישה אתמול.
examples.translation: You raised the issue in the meeting yesterday.

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱלֵיתְ את המחיר בלי להתריע.
examples.translation: You raised the price without warning.

leha'alot.notes: The Hif'il form of עלה means 'to raise' or 'to lift,' used both physically (e.g., lifting an object) and metaphorically (e.g., raising a topic).

idioms.usage: הַמְּפַקֵּד הֶעֱלָה אֶת הַמּוֹרָל שֶׁל הַחַיָּלִים. (The commander raised the soldiers' morale.)

examples.hebrew: הִפַּלְתִּי את הכוס על הרצפה.
examples.translation: I dropped the glass on the floor.

examples.hebrew: הִפַּלְתָּ את הכוס על הרצפה.
examples.translation: You dropped the glass on the floor.

examples.hebrew: כְּשֶׁהִפַּלְתְּ אֶת הַכּוֹס, הִתְנַפֵּץ הַזְּכוּכִית.
examples.translation: When you dropped the glass, the glass shattered.

lehafil.notes: The Hif'il form of נפל means 'to cause to fall' or 'to drop,' used both literally (e.g., dropping an object) and figuratively (e.g., causing failure).

idioms.trl: to drop the curtain (to reveal something)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִפִּיל אֶת הַמַּסָּךְ עַל הַתָּכְנִית. (He revealed the plan.)

examples.hebrew: רִכַּזְתִּי אֶת כָּל הַמִּידַע בְּמִסְמָךְ אֶחָד.
examples.translation: I centralized all the information into one document.

examples.hebrew: רִכַּזְתָּ אֶת כָּל הַמִּסְמָכִים בְּתִיקִיָה אַחַת.
examples.translation: You centralized all the documents into one folder.

examples.hebrew: רִכַּזְתְּ אֶת כָּל הַמִּדְעוֹת בְּסוֹף הַדּוֹחַ.
examples.translation: You centralized all the information at the end of the report.

lerakez.notes: The Pi'el form of the root ר-כ-ז typically means to centralize or concentrate something, often used in administrative or organizational contexts.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת רִכֵּז מַאֲמָצִים לְהַשְׁלִים אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט. (The team centralized efforts to complete the project.)

examples.hebrew: הִתְרַמְתִּי בְּגָדִים לְאֲנָשִׁים נִזְקָקִים.
examples.translation: I donated clothes to people in need.

examples.hebrew: הִתְרַמְתָּ כסף לקרן הצדקה האחרונה שעזרה למשפחות נזקקות.
examples.translation: You donated money to the recent charity fund that helped needy families.

examples.hebrew: הִתְרַמְתְּ לַמּוֹסָד הַצְּדָקָה בְּשָׁנָה שָׁעָבְרָה.
examples.translation: You donated to the charity last year.

lehatrim.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ת-ר-ם typically means to donate or contribute, often used in contexts of charity or support.

idioms.trl: to donate for the sake of
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְרִים לְמַעַן הַצְּדָקָה. (He donated for the sake of charity.)

examples.hebrew: סָפַרְתִּי אֶת כָּל הַכּוֹכָבִים בַּשָּׁמַיִם.
examples.translation: I counted all the stars in the sky.

examples.hebrew: כמה כוכבים סָפַרְתָּ בשמיים?
examples.translation: How many stars did you count in the sky?

examples.hebrew: את סָפַרְתְּ את כל הכוכבים בשמיים?
examples.translation: Did you count all the stars in the sky?

lispor.notes: Pa'al is the simple active form. For ספר, it primarily means 'to count' or 'to number'. It can also mean 'to tell a story' in some contexts, but this entry focuses on counting.

mng: to be caused to be counted (rare)

examples.hebrew: שָׁמַעְתִּי שַׁתִּי לְשִׁיר חָדָשׁ בַּרָדִיו.
examples.translation: I heard a new song on the radio.

examples.hebrew: שָׁמַעְתָּ את הקול שלה בטלפון?
examples.translation: Did you hear her voice on the phone?

examples.hebrew: שָׁמַעְתְּ כבר את החדשות?
examples.translation: Have you already heard the news?

examples.hebrew: מָצָאתִי סֵפֶר יָשָׁן בַּמִּרְתָּף.
examples.translation: I found an old book in the basement.

examples.hebrew: מָצָאתָ את המפתחות בסוף?
examples.translation: Did you find the keys in the end?

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מָצָאת אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ תַּחַת הַכַּר
examples.translation: I found the key under the pillow.

examples.hebrew: אמש יָשַׁבְתִּי בגינה עם הספר האהוב עליי.
examples.translation: Last night I sat in the garden with my favorite book.

examples.hebrew: בְּאֵיזֶה כִּסֵּא יָשַׁבְתָּ אֶתְמוֹל בַּמֶּרְכָּז?
examples.translation: Which chair did you sit on yesterday in the center?

examples.hebrew: אחרי שיָשַׁבְתְּ בחוץ כל היום, בטח התעייפת.
examples.translation: After you sat outside all day, you must be tired.

examples.hebrew: עָלִיתִי לְהַר הַכַּרְמֶל בַּבֹּקֶר.
examples.translation: I climbed Mount Carmel in the morning.

examples.hebrew: כשעָלִיתָ על ההר, מה ראית?
examples.translation: When you climbed the mountain, what did you see?

examples.hebrew: עָלִית לְהַר הַכַּרְמֶל בְּשַׁבָּת שָׁמַיִם.
examples.translation: You climbed Mount Carmel on a clear sky Saturday.

examples.hebrew: עָמַדְתִּי בתור לפחות שעה עד שהגיע תורי.
examples.translation: I stood in line for at least an hour until it was my turn.

examples.hebrew: עָמַדְתָּ בַּתּוֹר לִקְנוֹת כָּרְטִיסִים לַהוֹפָעָה.
examples.translation: You stood in line to buy tickets for the show.

examples.hebrew: עָמַדְתְּ לִפְנֵי הַמַּרְאָה וְסִרַקְתְּ אֶת שְׂעָרֵךְ.
examples.translation: You stood in front of the mirror and combed your hair.

examples.hebrew: עָשִׂיתִי את כל המטלות שלי היום.
examples.translation: I did all my chores today.

examples.hebrew: עָשִׂיתָ עֲבוֹדָה מְצוּיָנֶת הַיּוֹם.
examples.translation: You did an excellent job today.

examples.hebrew: מה עשית אתמול בערב?
examples.translation: What did you do last night?

examples.hebrew: בַּבּוֹקֶר כְּשֶׁקַּמְתִּי נָפַלְתִּי מִן הַמִּטָּה.
examples.translation: In the morning when I got up, I fell out of bed.

examples.hebrew: כשהנסעתי על האופניים, נָפַלְתָּ ושרטת את הברך.
examples.translation: When you were riding your bike, you fell and scraped your knee.

examples.hebrew: נָפַלְתְּ מהעץ וכאב לך המותן.
examples.translation: You fell from the tree and hurt your hip.

examples.hebrew: סָבַרְתִּי שֶׁהַיּוֹם יִהְיֶה חַם, אֲבָל טָעִיתִי.
examples.translation: I thought that today would be hot, but I was wrong.

examples.hebrew: הוא סָבַר שהוא יכול לעשות את זה לבד.
examples.translation: He thought he could do it alone.

examples.hebrew: אני סובר שהוא יגיע בזמן.
examples.translation: I think he will arrive on time.

examples.hebrew: בָּטַחְתִּי בוֹ וְהוּא אֱמֵת.
examples.translation: I trusted him and he was truthful.

examples.hebrew: בָּטַחְתָּ בוֹ, וְהוּא אֲכֵן עָזַר לְךָ.
examples.translation: You trusted him, and he indeed helped you.

examples.hebrew: בָּטַחְתְּ בִּי וְאֵינִי מֵכְזֵב אוֹתָךְ.
examples.translation: You trusted me and I will not let you down.

examples.hebrew: תַּחַלְתִּי לכתוב את הספר הזה בשנה שעברה.
examples.translation: I began writing this book last year.

examples.hebrew: כשתַּחַלְתָּ לדבר, כולם השתתקו והקשיבו.
examples.translation: When you started speaking, everyone fell silent and listened.

examples.hebrew: תַּחַלְתְּ לְסַפֵּר לִי אֶת הַסִּפּוּר בּוֹקֵר אֶחָד.
examples.translation: You began to tell me the story one morning.
